speaker: CANTERBURY
text_entry: Therefore doth heaven divide

speaker: CANTERBURY
text_entry: The state of man in divers functions,

speaker: CANTERBURY
text_entry: Setting endeavour in continual motion;

speaker: CANTERBURY
text_entry: To which is fixed, as an aim or butt,

speaker: CANTERBURY
text_entry: Obedience: for so work the honey-bees,

speaker: CANTERBURY
text_entry: Creatures that by a rule in nature teach

speaker: CANTERBURY
text_entry: The act of order to a peopled kingdom.

speaker: CANTERBURY
text_entry: They have a king and officers of sorts;

speaker: CANTERBURY
text_entry: Where some, like magistrates, correct at home,

speaker: CANTERBURY
text_entry: Others, like merchants, venture trade abroad,

speaker: CANTERBURY
text_entry: Others, like soldiers, armed in their stings,

speaker: CANTERBURY
text_entry: Make boot upon the summer's velvet buds,

speaker: CANTERBURY
text_entry: Which pillage they with merry march bring home

speaker: CANTERBURY
text_entry: To the tent-royal of their emperor;

speaker: CANTERBURY
text_entry: Who, busied in his majesty, surveys

speaker: CANTERBURY
text_entry: The singing masons building roofs of gold,

speaker: CANTERBURY
text_entry: The civil citizens kneading up the honey,

speaker: CANTERBURY
text_entry: The poor mechanic porters crowding in

speaker: CANTERBURY
text_entry: Their heavy burdens at his narrow gate,

speaker: CANTERBURY
text_entry: The sad-eyed justice, with his surly hum,

speaker: CANTERBURY
text_entry: Delivering o'er to executors pale

speaker: CANTERBURY
text_entry: The lazy yawning drone. I this infer,

speaker: CANTERBURY
text_entry: That many things, having full reference

speaker: CANTERBURY
text_entry: To one consent, may work contrariously:

speaker: CANTERBURY
text_entry: As many arrows, loosed several ways,

speaker: CANTERBURY
text_entry: Come to one mark; as many ways meet in one town;

speaker: CANTERBURY
text_entry: As many fresh streams meet in one salt sea;

speaker: CANTERBURY
text_entry: As many lines close in the dial's centre;

speaker: CANTERBURY
text_entry: So may a thousand actions, once afoot.

speaker: CANTERBURY
text_entry: End in one purpose, and be all well borne

speaker: CANTERBURY
text_entry: Without defeat. Therefore to France, my liege.

speaker: CANTERBURY
text_entry: Divide your happy England into four;

speaker: CANTERBURY
text_entry: Whereof take you one quarter into France,

speaker: CANTERBURY
text_entry: And you withal shall make all Gallia shake.

speaker: CANTERBURY
text_entry: If we, with thrice such powers left at home,

speaker: CANTERBURY
text_entry: Cannot defend our own doors from the dog,

speaker: CANTERBURY
text_entry: Let us be worried and our nation lose

speaker: CANTERBURY
text_entry: The name of hardiness and policy.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Call in the messengers sent from the Dauphin.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Exeunt some Attendants

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Now are we well resolved; and, by God's help,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: And yours, the noble sinews of our power,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: France being ours, we'll bend it to our awe,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Or break it all to pieces: or there we'll sit,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Ruling in large and ample empery

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: O'er France and all her almost kingly dukedoms,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Or lay these bones in an unworthy urn,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Tombless, with no remembrance over them:

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Either our history shall with full mouth

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Speak freely of our acts, or else our grave,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Like Turkish mute, shall have a tongueless mouth,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Not worshipp'd with a waxen epitaph.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Enter Ambassadors of France

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Now are we well prepared to know the pleasure

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Of our fair cousin Dauphin; for we hear

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Your greeting is from him, not from the king.

speaker: First Ambassador
text_entry: May't please your majesty to give us leave

speaker: First Ambassador
text_entry: Freely to render what we have in charge;

speaker: First Ambassador
text_entry: Or shall we sparingly show you far off

speaker: First Ambassador
text_entry: The Dauphin's meaning and our embassy?

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: We are no tyrant, but a Christian king;

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Unto whose grace our passion is as subject

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: As are our wretches fetter'd in our prisons:

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Therefore with frank and with uncurbed plainness

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Tell us the Dauphin's mind.

speaker: First Ambassador
text_entry: Thus, then, in few.

speaker: First Ambassador
text_entry: Your highness, lately sending into France,

speaker: First Ambassador
text_entry: Did claim some certain dukedoms, in the right

speaker: First Ambassador
text_entry: Of your great predecessor, King Edward the Third.

speaker: First Ambassador
text_entry: In answer of which claim, the prince our master

speaker: First Ambassador
text_entry: Says that you savour too much of your youth,

speaker: First Ambassador
text_entry: And bids you be advised there's nought in France

speaker: First Ambassador
text_entry: That can be with a nimble galliard won;

speaker: First Ambassador
text_entry: You cannot revel into dukedoms there.

speaker: First Ambassador
text_entry: He therefore sends you, meeter for your spirit,

speaker: First Ambassador
text_entry: This tun of treasure; and, in lieu of this,

speaker: First Ambassador
text_entry: Desires you let the dukedoms that you claim

speaker: First Ambassador
text_entry: Hear no more of you. This the Dauphin speaks.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: What treasure, uncle?

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: Tennis-balls, my liege.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: We are glad the Dauphin is so pleasant with us;

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: His present and your pains we thank you for:

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: When we have march'd our rackets to these balls,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: We will, in France, by God's grace, play a set

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Shall strike his father's crown into the hazard.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Tell him he hath made a match with such a wrangler

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: That all the courts of France will be disturb'd

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: With chaces. And we understand him well,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: How he comes o'er us with our wilder days,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Not measuring what use we made of them.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: We never valued this poor seat of England;

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: And therefore, living hence, did give ourself

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: To barbarous licence; as 'tis ever common

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: That men are merriest when they are from home.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: But tell the Dauphin I will keep my state,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Be like a king and show my sail of greatness

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: When I do rouse me in my throne of France:

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: For that I have laid by my majesty

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: And plodded like a man for working-days,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: But I will rise there with so full a glory

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: That I will dazzle all the eyes of France,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Yea, strike the Dauphin blind to look on us.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: And tell the pleasant prince this mock of his

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Hath turn'd his balls to gun-stones; and his soul

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Shall stand sore charged for the wasteful vengeance

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: That shall fly with them: for many a thousand widows

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Shall this his mock mock out of their dear husbands;

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Mock mothers from their sons, mock castles down;

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: And some are yet ungotten and unborn

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: That shall have cause to curse the Dauphin's scorn.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: But this lies all within the will of God,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: To whom I do appeal; and in whose name

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Tell you the Dauphin I am coming on,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: To venge me as I may and to put forth

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: My rightful hand in a well-hallow'd cause.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: So get you hence in peace; and tell the Dauphin

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: His jest will savour but of shallow wit,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: When thousands weep more than did laugh at it.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Convey them with safe conduct. Fare you well.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Exeunt Ambassadors

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: This was a merry message.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: We hope to make the sender blush at it.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Therefore, my lords, omit no happy hour

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: That may give furtherance to our expedition;

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: For we have now no thought in us but France,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Save those to God, that run before our business.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Therefore let our proportions for these wars

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Be soon collected and all things thought upon

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: That may with reasonable swiftness add

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: More feathers to our wings; for, God before,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: We'll chide this Dauphin at his father's door.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Therefore let every man now task his thought,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: That this fair action may on foot be brought.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Exeunt. Flourish

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: ACT II

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: PROLOGUE

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Enter Chorus

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: Now all the youth of England are on fire,

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: And silken dalliance in the wardrobe lies:

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: Now thrive the armourers, and honour's thought

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: Reigns solely in the breast of every man:

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: They sell the pasture now to buy the horse,

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: Following the mirror of all Christian kings,

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: With winged heels, as English Mercuries.

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: For now sits Expectation in the air,

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: And hides a sword from hilts unto the point

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: With crowns imperial, crowns and coronets,

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: Promised to Harry and his followers.

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: The French, advised by good intelligence

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: Of this most dreadful preparation,

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: Shake in their fear and with pale policy

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: Seek to divert the English purposes.

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: O England! model to thy inward greatness,

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: Like little body with a mighty heart,

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: What mightst thou do, that honour would thee do,

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: Were all thy children kind and natural!

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: But see thy fault! France hath in thee found out

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: A nest of hollow bosoms, which he fills

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: With treacherous crowns; and three corrupted men,

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: One, Richard Earl of Cambridge, and the second,

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: Henry Lord Scroop of Masham, and the third,

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: Sir Thomas Grey, knight, of Northumberland,

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: Have, for the gilt of France,--O guilt indeed!

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: Confirm'd conspiracy with fearful France;

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: And by their hands this grace of kings must die,

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: If hell and treason hold their promises,

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: Ere he take ship for France, and in Southampton.

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: Linger your patience on; and we'll digest

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: The abuse of distance; force a play:

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: The sum is paid; the traitors are agreed;

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: The king is set from London; and the scene

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: Is now transported, gentles, to Southampton;

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: There is the playhouse now, there must you sit:

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: And thence to France shall we convey you safe,

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: And bring you back, charming the narrow seas

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: To give you gentle pass; for, if we may,

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: We'll not offend one stomach with our play.

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: But, till the king come forth, and not till then,

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: Unto Southampton do we shift our scene.

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: Exit

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: SCENE I. London. A street.

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: Enter Corporal NYM and Lieutenant BARDOLPH

speaker: BARDOLPH
text_entry: Well met, Corporal Nym.

speaker: NYM
text_entry: Good morrow, Lieutenant Bardolph.

speaker: BARDOLPH
text_entry: What, are Ancient Pistol and you friends yet?

speaker: NYM
text_entry: For my part, I care not: I say little; but when

speaker: NYM
text_entry: time shall serve, there shall be smiles; but that

speaker: NYM
text_entry: shall be as it may. I dare not fight; but I will

speaker: NYM
text_entry: wink and hold out mine iron: it is a simple one; but

speaker: NYM
text_entry: what though? it will toast cheese, and it will

speaker: NYM
text_entry: endure cold as another man's sword will: and

speaker: NYM
text_entry: there's an end.

speaker: BARDOLPH
text_entry: I will bestow a breakfast to make you friends; and

speaker: BARDOLPH
text_entry: we'll be all three sworn brothers to France: let it

speaker: BARDOLPH
text_entry: be so, good Corporal Nym.

speaker: NYM
text_entry: Faith, I will live so long as I may, that's the

speaker: NYM
text_entry: certain of it; and when I cannot live any longer, I

speaker: NYM
text_entry: will do as I may: that is my rest, that is the

speaker: NYM
text_entry: rendezvous of it.

speaker: BARDOLPH
text_entry: It is certain, corporal, that he is married to Nell

speaker: BARDOLPH
text_entry: Quickly: and certainly she did you wrong; for you

speaker: BARDOLPH
text_entry: were troth-plight to her.

speaker: NYM
text_entry: I cannot tell: things must be as they may: men may

speaker: NYM
text_entry: sleep, and they may have their throats about them at

speaker: NYM
text_entry: that time; and some say knives have edges. It must

speaker: NYM
text_entry: be as it may: though patience be a tired mare, yet

speaker: NYM
text_entry: she will plod. There must be conclusions. Well, I

speaker: NYM
text_entry: cannot tell.

speaker: NYM
text_entry: Enter PISTOL and Hostess

speaker: BARDOLPH
text_entry: Here comes Ancient Pistol and his wife: good

speaker: BARDOLPH
text_entry: corporal, be patient here. How now, mine host Pistol!

speaker: PISTOL
text_entry: Base tike, call'st thou me host? Now, by this hand,

speaker: PISTOL
text_entry: I swear, I scorn the term; Nor shall my Nell keep lodgers.

speaker: Hostess
text_entry: No, by my troth, not long; for we cannot lodge and

speaker: Hostess
text_entry: board a dozen or fourteen gentlewomen that live

speaker: Hostess
text_entry: honestly by the prick of their needles, but it will

speaker: Hostess
text_entry: be thought we keep a bawdy house straight.

speaker: Hostess
text_entry: NYM and PISTOL draw

speaker: Hostess
text_entry: O well a day, Lady, if he be not drawn now! we

speaker: Hostess
text_entry: shall see wilful adultery and murder committed.

speaker: BARDOLPH
text_entry: Good lieutenant! good corporal! offer nothing here.

speaker: NYM
text_entry: Pish!

speaker: PISTOL
text_entry: Pish for thee, Iceland dog! thou prick-ear'd cur of Iceland!

speaker: Hostess
text_entry: Good Corporal Nym, show thy valour, and put up your sword.

speaker: NYM
text_entry: Will you shog off? I would have you solus.

speaker: PISTOL
text_entry: 'Solus,' egregious dog? O viper vile!

speaker: PISTOL
text_entry: The 'solus' in thy most mervailous face;

speaker: PISTOL
text_entry: The 'solus' in thy teeth, and in thy throat,

speaker: PISTOL
text_entry: And in thy hateful lungs, yea, in thy maw, perdy,

speaker: PISTOL
text_entry: And, which is worse, within thy nasty mouth!

speaker: PISTOL
text_entry: I do retort the 'solus' in thy bowels;

speaker: PISTOL
text_entry: For I can take, and Pistol's cock is up,

speaker: PISTOL
text_entry: And flashing fire will follow.

speaker: NYM
text_entry: I am not Barbason; you cannot conjure me. I have an

speaker: NYM
text_entry: humour to knock you indifferently well. If you grow

speaker: NYM
text_entry: foul with me, Pistol, I will scour you with my

speaker: NYM
text_entry: rapier, as I may, in fair terms: if you would walk

speaker: NYM
text_entry: off, I would prick your guts a little, in good

speaker: NYM
text_entry: terms, as I may: and that's the humour of it.

speaker: PISTOL
text_entry: O braggart vile and damned furious wight!

speaker: PISTOL
text_entry: The grave doth gape, and doting death is near;

speaker: PISTOL
text_entry: Therefore exhale.

speaker: BARDOLPH
text_entry: Hear me, hear me what I say: he that strikes the

speaker: BARDOLPH
text_entry: first stroke, I'll run him up to the hilts, as I am a soldier.

speaker: BARDOLPH
text_entry: Draws

speaker: PISTOL
text_entry: An oath of mickle might; and fury shall abate.

speaker: PISTOL
text_entry: Give me thy fist, thy fore-foot to me give:

speaker: PISTOL
text_entry: Thy spirits are most tall.

speaker: NYM
text_entry: I will cut thy throat, one time or other, in fair

speaker: NYM
text_entry: terms: that is the humour of it.

speaker: PISTOL
text_entry: 'Couple a gorge!'

speaker: PISTOL
text_entry: That is the word. I thee defy again.

speaker: PISTOL
text_entry: O hound of Crete, think'st thou my spouse to get?

speaker: PISTOL
text_entry: No; to the spital go,

speaker: PISTOL
text_entry: And from the powdering tub of infamy

speaker: PISTOL
text_entry: Fetch forth the lazar kite of Cressid's kind,

speaker: PISTOL
text_entry: Doll Tearsheet she by name, and her espouse:

speaker: PISTOL
text_entry: I have, and I will hold, the quondam Quickly

speaker: PISTOL
text_entry: For the only she; and--pauca, there's enough. Go to.

speaker: PISTOL
text_entry: Enter the Boy

speaker: Boy
text_entry: Mine host Pistol, you must come to my master, and

speaker: Boy
text_entry: you, hostess: he is very sick, and would to bed.

speaker: Boy
text_entry: Good Bardolph, put thy face between his sheets, and

speaker: Boy
text_entry: do the office of a warming-pan. Faith, he's very ill.

speaker: BARDOLPH
text_entry: Away, you rogue!

speaker: Hostess
text_entry: By my troth, he'll yield the crow a pudding one of

speaker: Hostess
text_entry: these days. The king has killed his heart. Good

speaker: Hostess
text_entry: husband, come home presently.

speaker: Hostess
text_entry: Exeunt Hostess and Boy

speaker: BARDOLPH
text_entry: Come, shall I make you two friends? We must to

speaker: BARDOLPH
text_entry: France together: why the devil should we keep

speaker: BARDOLPH
text_entry: knives to cut one another's throats?

speaker: PISTOL
text_entry: Let floods o'erswell, and fiends for food howl on!

speaker: NYM
text_entry: You'll pay me the eight shillings I won of you at betting?

speaker: PISTOL
text_entry: Base is the slave that pays.

speaker: NYM
text_entry: That now I will have: that's the humour of it.

speaker: PISTOL
text_entry: As manhood shall compound: push home.

speaker: PISTOL
text_entry: They draw

speaker: BARDOLPH
text_entry: By this sword, he that makes the first thrust, I'll

speaker: BARDOLPH
text_entry: kill him; by this sword, I will.

speaker: PISTOL
text_entry: Sword is an oath, and oaths must have their course.

speaker: BARDOLPH
text_entry: Corporal Nym, an thou wilt be friends, be friends:

speaker: BARDOLPH
text_entry: an thou wilt not, why, then, be enemies with me too.

speaker: BARDOLPH
text_entry: Prithee, put up.

speaker: NYM
text_entry: I shall have my eight shillings I won of you at betting?

speaker: PISTOL
text_entry: A noble shalt thou have, and present pay;

speaker: PISTOL
text_entry: And liquor likewise will I give to thee,

speaker: PISTOL
text_entry: And friendship shall combine, and brotherhood:

speaker: PISTOL
text_entry: I'll live by Nym, and Nym shall live by me;

speaker: PISTOL
text_entry: Is not this just? for I shall sutler be

speaker: PISTOL
text_entry: Unto the camp, and profits will accrue.

speaker: PISTOL
text_entry: Give me thy hand.

speaker: NYM
text_entry: I shall have my noble?

speaker: PISTOL
text_entry: In cash most justly paid.

speaker: NYM
text_entry: Well, then, that's the humour of't.

speaker: NYM
text_entry: Re-enter Hostess

speaker: Hostess
text_entry: As ever you came of women, come in quickly to Sir

speaker: Hostess
text_entry: John. Ah, poor heart! he is so shaked of a burning

speaker: Hostess
text_entry: quotidian tertian, that it is most lamentable to

speaker: Hostess
text_entry: behold. Sweet men, come to him.

speaker: NYM
text_entry: The king hath run bad humours on the knight; that's

speaker: NYM
text_entry: the even of it.

speaker: PISTOL
text_entry: Nym, thou hast spoke the right;

speaker: PISTOL
text_entry: His heart is fracted and corroborate.

speaker: NYM
text_entry: The king is a good king: but it must be as it may;

speaker: NYM
text_entry: he passes some humours and careers.

speaker: PISTOL
text_entry: Let us condole the knight; for, lambkins we will live.

speaker: PISTOL
text_entry: SCENE II. Southampton. A council-chamber.

speaker: PISTOL
text_entry: Enter EXETER, BEDFORD, and WESTMORELAND

speaker: BEDFORD
text_entry: 'Fore God, his grace is bold, to trust these traitors.

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: They shall be apprehended by and by.

speaker: WESTMORELAND
text_entry: How smooth and even they do bear themselves!

speaker: WESTMORELAND
text_entry: As if allegiance in their bosoms sat,

speaker: WESTMORELAND
text_entry: Crowned with faith and constant loyalty.

speaker: BEDFORD
text_entry: The king hath note of all that they intend,

speaker: BEDFORD
text_entry: By interception which they dream not of.

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: Nay, but the man that was his bedfellow,

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: Whom he hath dull'd and cloy'd with gracious favours,

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: That he should, for a foreign purse, so sell

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: His sovereign's life to death and treachery.

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: Trumpets sound. Enter KING HENRY V, SCROOP, CAMBRIDGE, GREY, and Attendants

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Now sits the wind fair, and we will aboard.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: My Lord of Cambridge, and my kind Lord of Masham,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: And you, my gentle knight, give me your thoughts:

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Ambassadors from Harry King of England

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Do crave admittance to your majesty.

speaker: KING OF FRANCE
text_entry: We'll give them present audience. Go, and bring them.

speaker: KING OF FRANCE
text_entry: Exeunt Messenger and certain Lords

speaker: KING OF FRANCE
text_entry: You see this chase is hotly follow'd, friends.

speaker: DAUPHIN
text_entry: Turn head, and stop pursuit; for coward dogs

speaker: DAUPHIN
text_entry: Most spend their mouths when what they seem to threaten

speaker: DAUPHIN
text_entry: Runs far before them. Good my sovereign,

speaker: DAUPHIN
text_entry: Take up the English short, and let them know

speaker: DAUPHIN
text_entry: Of what a monarchy you are the head:

speaker: DAUPHIN
text_entry: Self-love, my liege, is not so vile a sin

speaker: DAUPHIN
text_entry: As self-neglecting.

speaker: DAUPHIN
text_entry: Re-enter Lords, with EXETER and train

speaker: KING OF FRANCE
text_entry: From our brother England?

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: From him; and thus he greets your majesty.

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: He wills you, in the name of God Almighty,

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: That you divest yourself, and lay apart

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: The borrow'd glories that by gift of heaven,

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: By law of nature and of nations, 'long

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: To him and to his heirs; namely, the crown

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: And all wide-stretched honours that pertain

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: By custom and the ordinance of times

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: Unto the crown of France. That you may know

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: 'Tis no sinister nor no awkward claim,

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: Pick'd from the worm-holes of long-vanish'd days,

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: Nor from the dust of old oblivion raked,

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: He sends you this most memorable line,

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: In every branch truly demonstrative;

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: Willing to overlook this pedigree:

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: And when you find him evenly derived

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: From his most famed of famous ancestors,

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: Edward the Third, he bids you then resign

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: Your crown and kingdom, indirectly held

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: From him the native and true challenger.

speaker: KING OF FRANCE
text_entry: Or else what follows?

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: Bloody constraint; for if you hide the crown

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: Even in your hearts, there will he rake for it:

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: Therefore in fierce tempest is he coming,

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: In thunder and in earthquake, like a Jove,

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: That, if requiring fail, he will compel;

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: And bids you, in the bowels of the Lord,

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: Deliver up the crown, and to take mercy

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: On the poor souls for whom this hungry war

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: Opens his vasty jaws; and on your head

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: Turning the widows' tears, the orphans' cries

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: The dead men's blood, the pining maidens groans,

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: For husbands, fathers and betrothed lovers,

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: That shall be swallow'd in this controversy.

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: This is his claim, his threatening and my message;

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: Unless the Dauphin be in presence here,

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: To whom expressly I bring greeting too.

speaker: KING OF FRANCE
text_entry: For us, we will consider of this further:

speaker: KING OF FRANCE
text_entry: To-morrow shall you bear our full intent

speaker: KING OF FRANCE
text_entry: Back to our brother England.

speaker: DAUPHIN
text_entry: For the Dauphin,

speaker: DAUPHIN
text_entry: I stand here for him: what to him from England?

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: Scorn and defiance; slight regard, contempt,

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: And any thing that may not misbecome

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: The mighty sender, doth he prize you at.

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: Thus says my king; an' if your father's highness

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: Do not, in grant of all demands at large,

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: Sweeten the bitter mock you sent his majesty,

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: He'll call you to so hot an answer of it,

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: That caves and womby vaultages of France

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: Shall chide your trespass and return your mock

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: In second accent of his ordnance.

speaker: DAUPHIN
text_entry: Say, if my father render fair return,

speaker: DAUPHIN
text_entry: It is against my will; for I desire

speaker: DAUPHIN
text_entry: Nothing but odds with England: to that end,

speaker: DAUPHIN
text_entry: As matching to his youth and vanity,

speaker: DAUPHIN
text_entry: I did present him with the Paris balls.

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: He'll make your Paris Louvre shake for it,

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: Were it the mistress-court of mighty Europe:

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: And, be assured, you'll find a difference,

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: As we his subjects have in wonder found,

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: Between the promise of his greener days

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: And these he masters now: now he weighs time

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: Even to the utmost grain: that you shall read

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: In your own losses, if he stay in France.

speaker: KING OF FRANCE
text_entry: To-morrow shall you know our mind at full.

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: Dispatch us with all speed, lest that our king

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: Come here himself to question our delay;

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: For he is footed in this land already.

speaker: KING OF FRANCE
text_entry: You shall be soon dispatch's with fair conditions:

speaker: KING OF FRANCE
text_entry: A night is but small breath and little pause

speaker: KING OF FRANCE
text_entry: To answer matters of this consequence.

speaker: KING OF FRANCE
text_entry: Flourish. Exeunt

speaker: KING OF FRANCE
text_entry: ACT III

speaker: KING OF FRANCE
text_entry: PROLOGUE

speaker: KING OF FRANCE
text_entry: Enter Chorus

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: Thus with imagined wing our swift scene flies

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: In motion of no less celerity

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: Than that of thought. Suppose that you have seen

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: The well-appointed king at Hampton pier

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: Embark his royalty; and his brave fleet

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: With silken streamers the young Phoebus fanning:

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: Play with your fancies, and in them behold

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: Upon the hempen tackle ship-boys climbing;

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: Hear the shrill whistle which doth order give

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: To sounds confused; behold the threaden sails,

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: Borne with the invisible and creeping wind,

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: Draw the huge bottoms through the furrow'd sea,

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: Breasting the lofty surge: O, do but think

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: You stand upon the ravage and behold

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: A city on the inconstant billows dancing;

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: For so appears this fleet majestical,

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: Holding due course to Harfleur. Follow, follow:

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: Grapple your minds to sternage of this navy,

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: And leave your England, as dead midnight still,

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: Guarded with grandsires, babies and old women,

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: Either past or not arrived to pith and puissance;

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: For who is he, whose chin is but enrich'd

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: With one appearing hair, that will not follow

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: These cull'd and choice-drawn cavaliers to France?

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: Work, work your thoughts, and therein see a siege;

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: Behold the ordnance on their carriages,

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: With fatal mouths gaping on girded Harfleur.

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: Suppose the ambassador from the French comes back;

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: Tells Harry that the king doth offer him

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: Katharine his daughter, and with her, to dowry,

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: Some petty and unprofitable dukedoms.

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: The offer likes not: and the nimble gunner

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: With linstock now the devilish cannon touches,

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: Alarum, and chambers go off

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: And down goes all before them. Still be kind,

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: And eke out our performance with your mind.

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: Exit

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: SCENE I. France. Before Harfleur.

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: Alarum. Enter KING HENRY, EXETER, BEDFORD, GLOUCESTER, and Soldiers, with scaling-ladders

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Once more unto the breach, dear friends, once more;

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Or close the wall up with our English dead.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: In peace there's nothing so becomes a man

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: As modest stillness and humility:

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: But when the blast of war blows in our ears,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Then imitate the action of the tiger;

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Stiffen the sinews, summon up the blood,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Disguise fair nature with hard-favour'd rage;

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Then lend the eye a terrible aspect;

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Let pry through the portage of the head

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Like the brass cannon; let the brow o'erwhelm it

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: As fearfully as doth a galled rock

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: O'erhang and jutty his confounded base,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Swill'd with the wild and wasteful ocean.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Now set the teeth and stretch the nostril wide,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Hold hard the breath and bend up every spirit

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: To his full height. On, on, you noblest English.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Whose blood is fet from fathers of war-proof!

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Fathers that, like so many Alexanders,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Have in these parts from morn till even fought

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: And sheathed their swords for lack of argument:

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Dishonour not your mothers; now attest

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: That those whom you call'd fathers did beget you.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Be copy now to men of grosser blood,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: And teach them how to war. And you, good yeoman,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Whose limbs were made in England, show us here

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: The mettle of your pasture; let us swear

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: That you are worth your breeding; which I doubt not;

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: For there is none of you so mean and base,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: That hath not noble lustre in your eyes.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: I see you stand like greyhounds in the slips,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Straining upon the start. The game's afoot:

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Follow your spirit, and upon this charge

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Cry 'God for Harry, England, and Saint George!'

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Exeunt. Alarum, and chambers go off

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: SCENE II. The same.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Enter NYM, BARDOLPH, PISTOL, and Boy

speaker: BARDOLPH
text_entry: On, on, on, on, on! to the breach, to the breach!

speaker: NYM
text_entry: Pray thee, corporal, stay: the knocks are too hot;

speaker: NYM
text_entry: and, for mine own part, I have not a case of lives:

speaker: NYM
text_entry: the humour of it is too hot, that is the very

speaker: NYM
text_entry: plain-song of it.

speaker: PISTOL
text_entry: The plain-song is most just: for humours do abound:

speaker: PISTOL
text_entry: Knocks go and come; God's vassals drop and die;

speaker: PISTOL
text_entry: And sword and shield,

speaker: PISTOL
text_entry: In bloody field,

speaker: PISTOL
text_entry: Doth win immortal fame.

speaker: Boy
text_entry: Would I were in an alehouse in London! I would give

speaker: Boy
text_entry: all my fame for a pot of ale and safety.

speaker: PISTOL
text_entry: And I:

speaker: PISTOL
text_entry: If wishes would prevail with me,

speaker: PISTOL
text_entry: My purpose should not fail with me,

speaker: PISTOL
text_entry: But thither would I hie.

speaker: Boy
text_entry: As duly, but not as truly,

speaker: Boy
text_entry: As bird doth sing on bough.

speaker: Boy
text_entry: Enter FLUELLEN

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: Up to the breach, you dogs! avaunt, you cullions!

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: Driving them forward

speaker: PISTOL
text_entry: Be merciful, great duke, to men of mould.

speaker: PISTOL
text_entry: Abate thy rage, abate thy manly rage,

speaker: PISTOL
text_entry: Abate thy rage, great duke!

speaker: PISTOL
text_entry: Good bawcock, bate thy rage; use lenity, sweet chuck!

speaker: NYM
text_entry: These be good humours! your honour wins bad humours.

speaker: NYM
text_entry: Exeunt all but Boy

speaker: Boy
text_entry: As young as I am, I have observed these three

speaker: Boy
text_entry: swashers. I am boy to them all three: but all they

speaker: Boy
text_entry: three, though they would serve me, could not be man

speaker: Boy
text_entry: to me; for indeed three such antics do not amount to

speaker: Boy
text_entry: a man. For Bardolph, he is white-livered and

speaker: Boy
text_entry: red-faced; by the means whereof a' faces it out, but

speaker: Boy
text_entry: fights not. For Pistol, he hath a killing tongue

speaker: Boy
text_entry: and a quiet sword; by the means whereof a' breaks

speaker: Boy
text_entry: words, and keeps whole weapons. For Nym, he hath

speaker: Boy
text_entry: heard that men of few words are the best men; and

speaker: Boy
text_entry: therefore he scorns to say his prayers, lest a'

speaker: Boy
text_entry: should be thought a coward: but his few bad words

speaker: Boy
text_entry: are matched with as few good deeds; for a' never

speaker: Boy
text_entry: broke any man's head but his own, and that was

speaker: Boy
text_entry: against a post when he was drunk. They will steal

speaker: Boy
text_entry: any thing, and call it purchase. Bardolph stole a

speaker: Boy
text_entry: lute-case, bore it twelve leagues, and sold it for

speaker: Boy
text_entry: three half pence. Nym and Bardolph are sworn

speaker: Boy
text_entry: brothers in filching, and in Calais they stole a

speaker: Boy
text_entry: fire-shovel: I knew by that piece of service the

speaker: Boy
text_entry: men would carry coals. They would have me as

speaker: Boy
text_entry: familiar with men's pockets as their gloves or their

speaker: Boy
text_entry: handkerchers: which makes much against my manhood,

speaker: Boy
text_entry: if I should take from another's pocket to put into

speaker: Boy
text_entry: mine; for it is plain pocketing up of wrongs. I

speaker: Boy
text_entry: must leave them, and seek some better service:

speaker: Boy
text_entry: their villany goes against my weak stomach, and

speaker: Boy
text_entry: therefore I must cast it up.

speaker: Boy
text_entry: Exit

speaker: Boy
text_entry: Re-enter FLUELLEN, GOWER following

speaker: GOWER
text_entry: Captain Fluellen, you must come presently to the

speaker: GOWER
text_entry: mines; the Duke of Gloucester would speak with you.

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: To the mines! tell you the duke, it is not so good

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: to come to the mines; for, look you, the mines is

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: not according to the disciplines of the war: the

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: concavities of it is not sufficient; for, look you,

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: the athversary, you may discuss unto the duke, look

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: you, is digt himself four yard under the

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: countermines: by Cheshu, I think a' will plough up

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: all, if there is not better directions.

speaker: GOWER
text_entry: The Duke of Gloucester, to whom the order of the

speaker: GOWER
text_entry: siege is given, is altogether directed by an

speaker: GOWER
text_entry: Irishman, a very valiant gentleman, i' faith.

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: It is Captain Macmorris, is it not?

speaker: GOWER
text_entry: I think it be.

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: By Cheshu, he is an ass, as in the world: I will

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: verify as much in his beard: be has no more

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: directions in the true disciplines of the wars, look

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: you, of the Roman disciplines, than is a puppy-dog.

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: Enter MACMORRIS and Captain JAMY

speaker: GOWER
text_entry: Here a' comes; and the Scots captain, Captain Jamy, with him.

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: Captain Jamy is a marvellous falourous gentleman,

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: that is certain; and of great expedition and

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: knowledge in th' aunchient wars, upon my particular

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: knowledge of his directions: by Cheshu, he will

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: maintain his argument as well as any military man in

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: the world, in the disciplines of the pristine wars

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: of the Romans.

speaker: JAMY
text_entry: I say gud-day, Captain Fluellen.

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: God-den to your worship, good Captain James.

speaker: GOWER
text_entry: How now, Captain Macmorris! have you quit the

speaker: GOWER
text_entry: mines? have the pioneers given o'er?

speaker: MACMORRIS
text_entry: By Chrish, la! tish ill done: the work ish give

speaker: MACMORRIS
text_entry: over, the trompet sound the retreat. By my hand, I

speaker: MACMORRIS
text_entry: swear, and my father's soul, the work ish ill done;

speaker: MACMORRIS
text_entry: it ish give over: I would have blowed up the town, so

speaker: MACMORRIS
text_entry: Chrish save me, la! in an hour: O, tish ill done,

speaker: MACMORRIS
text_entry: tish ill done; by my hand, tish ill done!

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: Captain Macmorris, I beseech you now, will you

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: voutsafe me, look you, a few disputations with you,

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: as partly touching or concerning the disciplines of

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: the war, the Roman wars, in the way of argument,

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: look you, and friendly communication; partly to

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: satisfy my opinion, and partly for the satisfaction,

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: look you, of my mind, as touching the direction of

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: the military discipline; that is the point.

speaker: JAMY
text_entry: It sall be vary gud, gud feith, gud captains bath:

speaker: JAMY
text_entry: and I sall quit you with gud leve, as I may pick

speaker: JAMY
text_entry: occasion; that sall I, marry.

speaker: MACMORRIS
text_entry: It is no time to discourse, so Chrish save me: the

speaker: MACMORRIS
text_entry: day is hot, and the weather, and the wars, and the

speaker: MACMORRIS
text_entry: king, and the dukes: it is no time to discourse. The

speaker: MACMORRIS
text_entry: town is beseeched, and the trumpet call us to the

speaker: MACMORRIS
text_entry: breach; and we talk, and, be Chrish, do nothing:

speaker: MACMORRIS
text_entry: 'tis shame for us all: so God sa' me, 'tis shame to

speaker: MACMORRIS
text_entry: stand still; it is shame, by my hand: and there is

speaker: MACMORRIS
text_entry: throats to be cut, and works to be done; and there

speaker: MACMORRIS
text_entry: ish nothing done, so Chrish sa' me, la!

speaker: JAMY
text_entry: By the mess, ere theise eyes of mine take themselves

speaker: JAMY
text_entry: to slomber, ay'll de gud service, or ay'll lig i'

speaker: JAMY
text_entry: the grund for it; ay, or go to death; and ay'll pay

speaker: JAMY
text_entry: 't as valourously as I may, that sall I suerly do,

speaker: JAMY
text_entry: that is the breff and the long. Marry, I wad full

speaker: JAMY
text_entry: fain hear some question 'tween you tway.

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: Captain Macmorris, I think, look you, under your

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: correction, there is not many of your nation--

speaker: MACMORRIS
text_entry: Of my nation! What ish my nation? Ish a villain,

speaker: MACMORRIS
text_entry: and a bastard, and a knave, and a rascal. What ish

speaker: MACMORRIS
text_entry: my nation? Who talks of my nation?

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: Look you, if you take the matter otherwise than is

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: meant, Captain Macmorris, peradventure I shall think

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: you do not use me with that affability as in

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: discretion you ought to use me, look you: being as

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: good a man as yourself, both in the disciplines of

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: war, and in the derivation of my birth, and in

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: other particularities.

speaker: MACMORRIS
text_entry: I do not know you so good a man as myself: so

speaker: MACMORRIS
text_entry: Chrish save me, I will cut off your head.

speaker: GOWER
text_entry: Gentlemen both, you will mistake each other.

speaker: JAMY
text_entry: A! that's a foul fault.

speaker: JAMY
text_entry: A parley sounded

speaker: GOWER
text_entry: The town sounds a parley.

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: Captain Macmorris, when there is more better

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: opportunity to be required, look you, I will be so

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: bold as to tell you I know the disciplines of war;

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: and there is an end.

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: SCENE III. The same. Before the gates.

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: The Governor and some Citizens on the walls; the English forces below. Enter KING HENRY and his train

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: How yet resolves the governor of the town?

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: This is the latest parle we will admit;

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Therefore to our best mercy give yourselves;

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Or like to men proud of destruction

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Defy us to our worst: for, as I am a soldier,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: A name that in my thoughts becomes me best,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: If I begin the battery once again,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: I will not leave the half-achieved Harfleur

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Till in her ashes she lie buried.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: The gates of mercy shall be all shut up,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: And the flesh'd soldier, rough and hard of heart,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: In liberty of bloody hand shall range

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: With conscience wide as hell, mowing like grass

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Your fresh-fair virgins and your flowering infants.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: What is it then to me, if impious war,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Array'd in flames like to the prince of fiends,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Do, with his smirch'd complexion, all fell feats

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Enlink'd to waste and desolation?

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: What is't to me, when you yourselves are cause,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: If your pure maidens fall into the hand

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Of hot and forcing violation?

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: What rein can hold licentious wickedness

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: When down the hill he holds his fierce career?

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: We may as bootless spend our vain command

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Upon the enraged soldiers in their spoil

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: As send precepts to the leviathan

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: To come ashore. Therefore, you men of Harfleur,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Take pity of your town and of your people,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Whiles yet my soldiers are in my command;

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Whiles yet the cool and temperate wind of grace

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: O'erblows the filthy and contagious clouds

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Of heady murder, spoil and villany.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: If not, why, in a moment look to see

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: The blind and bloody soldier with foul hand

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Defile the locks of your shrill-shrieking daughters;

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Your fathers taken by the silver beards,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: And their most reverend heads dash'd to the walls,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Your naked infants spitted upon pikes,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Whiles the mad mothers with their howls confused

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Do break the clouds, as did the wives of Jewry

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: At Herod's bloody-hunting slaughtermen.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: What say you? will you yield, and this avoid,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Or, guilty in defence, be thus destroy'd?

speaker: GOVERNOR
text_entry: Our expectation hath this day an end:

speaker: GOVERNOR
text_entry: The Dauphin, whom of succors we entreated,

speaker: GOVERNOR
text_entry: Returns us that his powers are yet not ready

speaker: GOVERNOR
text_entry: To raise so great a siege. Therefore, great king,

speaker: GOVERNOR
text_entry: We yield our town and lives to thy soft mercy.

speaker: GOVERNOR
text_entry: Enter our gates; dispose of us and ours;

speaker: GOVERNOR
text_entry: For we no longer are defensible.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Open your gates. Come, uncle Exeter,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Go you and enter Harfleur; there remain,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: And fortify it strongly 'gainst the French:

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Use mercy to them all. For us, dear uncle,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: The winter coming on and sickness growing

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Upon our soldiers, we will retire to Calais.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: To-night in Harfleur we will be your guest;

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: To-morrow for the march are we addrest.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Flourish. The King and his train enter the town

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: SCENE IV. The FRENCH KING's palace.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Enter KATHARINE and ALICE

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: Alice, tu as ete en Angleterre, et tu parles bien le langage.

speaker: ALICE
text_entry: Un peu, madame.

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: Je te prie, m'enseignez: il faut que j'apprenne a

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: parler. Comment appelez-vous la main en Anglois?

speaker: ALICE
text_entry: La main? elle est appelee de hand.

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: De hand. Et les doigts?

speaker: ALICE
text_entry: Les doigts? ma foi, j'oublie les doigts; mais je me

speaker: ALICE
text_entry: souviendrai. Les doigts? je pense qu'ils sont

speaker: ALICE
text_entry: appeles de fingres; oui, de fingres.

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: La main, de hand; les doigts, de fingres. Je pense

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: que je suis le bon ecolier; j'ai gagne deux mots

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: d'Anglois vitement. Comment appelez-vous les ongles?

speaker: ALICE
text_entry: Les ongles? nous les appelons de nails.

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: De nails. Ecoutez; dites-moi, si je parle bien: de

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: hand, de fingres, et de nails.

speaker: ALICE
text_entry: C'est bien dit, madame; il est fort bon Anglois.

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: Dites-moi l'Anglois pour le bras.

speaker: ALICE
text_entry: De arm, madame.

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: Et le coude?

speaker: ALICE
text_entry: De elbow.

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: De elbow. Je m'en fais la repetition de tous les

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: mots que vous m'avez appris des a present.

speaker: ALICE
text_entry: Il est trop difficile, madame, comme je pense.

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: Excusez-moi, Alice; ecoutez: de hand, de fingres,

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: de nails, de arma, de bilbow.

speaker: ALICE
text_entry: De elbow, madame.

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: O Seigneur Dieu, je m'en oublie! de elbow. Comment

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: appelez-vous le col?

speaker: ALICE
text_entry: De neck, madame.

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: De nick. Et le menton?

speaker: ALICE
text_entry: De chin.

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: De sin. Le col, de nick; de menton, de sin.

speaker: ALICE
text_entry: Oui. Sauf votre honneur, en verite, vous prononcez

speaker: ALICE
text_entry: les mots aussi droit que les natifs d'Angleterre.

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: Je ne doute point d'apprendre, par la grace de Dieu,

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: et en peu de temps.

speaker: ALICE
text_entry: N'avez vous pas deja oublie ce que je vous ai enseigne?

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: Non, je reciterai a vous promptement: de hand, de

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: fingres, de mails--

speaker: ALICE
text_entry: De nails, madame.

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: De nails, de arm, de ilbow.

speaker: ALICE
text_entry: Sauf votre honneur, de elbow.

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: Ainsi dis-je; de elbow, de nick, et de sin. Comment

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: appelez-vous le pied et la robe?

speaker: ALICE
text_entry: De foot, madame; et de coun.

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: De foot et de coun! O Seigneur Dieu! ce sont mots

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: de son mauvais, corruptible, gros, et impudique, et

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: non pour les dames d'honneur d'user: je ne voudrais

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: prononcer ces mots devant les seigneurs de France

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: pour tout le monde. Foh! le foot et le coun!

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: Neanmoins, je reciterai une autre fois ma lecon

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: ensemble: de hand, de fingres, de nails, de arm, de

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: elbow, de nick, de sin, de foot, de coun.

speaker: ALICE
text_entry: Excellent, madame!

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: C'est assez pour une fois: allons-nous a diner.

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: SCENE V. The same.

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: Enter the KING OF FRANCE, the DAUPHIN, the DUKE oF BOURBON, the Constable Of France, and others

speaker: KING OF FRANCE
text_entry: 'Tis certain he hath pass'd the river Somme.

speaker: Constable
text_entry: And if he be not fought withal, my lord,

speaker: Constable
text_entry: Let us not live in France; let us quit all

speaker: Constable
text_entry: And give our vineyards to a barbarous people.

speaker: DAUPHIN
text_entry: O Dieu vivant! shall a few sprays of us,

speaker: DAUPHIN
text_entry: The emptying of our fathers' luxury,

speaker: DAUPHIN
text_entry: Our scions, put in wild and savage stock,

speaker: DAUPHIN
text_entry: Spirt up so suddenly into the clouds,

speaker: DAUPHIN
text_entry: And overlook their grafters?

speaker: BOURBON
text_entry: Normans, but bastard Normans, Norman bastards!

speaker: BOURBON
text_entry: Mort de ma vie! if they march along

speaker: BOURBON
text_entry: Unfought withal, but I will sell my dukedom,

speaker: BOURBON
text_entry: To buy a slobbery and a dirty farm

speaker: BOURBON
text_entry: In that nook-shotten isle of Albion.

speaker: Constable
text_entry: Dieu de batailles! where have they this mettle?

speaker: Constable
text_entry: Is not their climate foggy, raw and dull,

speaker: Constable
text_entry: On whom, as in despite, the sun looks pale,

speaker: Constable
text_entry: Killing their fruit with frowns? Can sodden water,

speaker: Constable
text_entry: A drench for sur-rein'd jades, their barley-broth,

speaker: Constable
text_entry: Decoct their cold blood to such valiant heat?

speaker: Constable
text_entry: And shall our quick blood, spirited with wine,

speaker: Constable
text_entry: Seem frosty? O, for honour of our land,

speaker: Constable
text_entry: Let us not hang like roping icicles

speaker: Constable
text_entry: Upon our houses' thatch, whiles a more frosty people

speaker: Constable
text_entry: Sweat drops of gallant youth in our rich fields!

speaker: Constable
text_entry: Poor we may call them in their native lords.

speaker: DAUPHIN
text_entry: By faith and honour,

speaker: DAUPHIN
text_entry: Our madams mock at us, and plainly say

speaker: DAUPHIN
text_entry: Our mettle is bred out and they will give

speaker: DAUPHIN
text_entry: Their bodies to the lust of English youth

speaker: DAUPHIN
text_entry: To new-store France with bastard warriors.

speaker: BOURBON
text_entry: They bid us to the English dancing-schools,

speaker: BOURBON
text_entry: And teach lavoltas high and swift corantos;

speaker: BOURBON
text_entry: Saying our grace is only in our heels,

speaker: BOURBON
text_entry: And that we are most lofty runaways.

speaker: KING OF FRANCE
text_entry: Where is Montjoy the herald? speed him hence:

speaker: KING OF FRANCE
text_entry: Let him greet England with our sharp defiance.

speaker: KING OF FRANCE
text_entry: Up, princes! and, with spirit of honour edged

speaker: KING OF FRANCE
text_entry: More sharper than your swords, hie to the field:

speaker: KING OF FRANCE
text_entry: Charles Delabreth, high constable of France;

speaker: KING OF FRANCE
text_entry: You Dukes of Orleans, Bourbon, and of Berri,

speaker: KING OF FRANCE
text_entry: Alencon, Brabant, Bar, and Burgundy;

speaker: KING OF FRANCE
text_entry: Jaques Chatillon, Rambures, Vaudemont,

speaker: KING OF FRANCE
text_entry: Beaumont, Grandpre, Roussi, and Fauconberg,

speaker: KING OF FRANCE
text_entry: Foix, Lestrale, Bouciqualt, and Charolois;

speaker: KING OF FRANCE
text_entry: High dukes, great princes, barons, lords and knights,

speaker: KING OF FRANCE
text_entry: For your great seats now quit you of great shames.

speaker: KING OF FRANCE
text_entry: Bar Harry England, that sweeps through our land

speaker: KING OF FRANCE
text_entry: With pennons painted in the blood of Harfleur:

speaker: KING OF FRANCE
text_entry: Rush on his host, as doth the melted snow

speaker: KING OF FRANCE
text_entry: Upon the valleys, whose low vassal seat

speaker: KING OF FRANCE
text_entry: The Alps doth spit and void his rheum upon:

speaker: KING OF FRANCE
text_entry: Go down upon him, you have power enough,

speaker: KING OF FRANCE
text_entry: And in a captive chariot into Rouen

speaker: KING OF FRANCE
text_entry: Bring him our prisoner.

speaker: Constable
text_entry: This becomes the great.

speaker: Constable
text_entry: Sorry am I his numbers are so few,

speaker: Constable
text_entry: His soldiers sick and famish'd in their march,

speaker: Constable
text_entry: For I am sure, when he shall see our army,

speaker: Constable
text_entry: He'll drop his heart into the sink of fear

speaker: Constable
text_entry: And for achievement offer us his ransom.

speaker: KING OF FRANCE
text_entry: Therefore, lord constable, haste on Montjoy.

speaker: KING OF FRANCE
text_entry: And let him say to England that we send

speaker: KING OF FRANCE
text_entry: To know what willing ransom he will give.

speaker: KING OF FRANCE
text_entry: Prince Dauphin, you shall stay with us in Rouen.

speaker: DAUPHIN
text_entry: Not so, I do beseech your majesty.

speaker: KING OF FRANCE
text_entry: Be patient, for you shall remain with us.

speaker: KING OF FRANCE
text_entry: Now forth, lord constable and princes all,

speaker: KING OF FRANCE
text_entry: And quickly bring us word of England's fall.

speaker: KING OF FRANCE
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: KING OF FRANCE
text_entry: SCENE VI. The English camp in Picardy.

speaker: KING OF FRANCE
text_entry: Enter GOWER and FLUELLEN, meeting

speaker: GOWER
text_entry: How now, Captain Fluellen! come you from the bridge?

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: I assure you, there is very excellent services

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: committed at the bridge.

speaker: GOWER
text_entry: Is the Duke of Exeter safe?

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: The Duke of Exeter is as magnanimous as Agamemnon;

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: and a man that I love and honour with my soul, and my

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: heart, and my duty, and my life, and my living, and

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: my uttermost power: he is not-God be praised and

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: blessed!--any hurt in the world; but keeps the

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: bridge most valiantly, with excellent discipline.

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: There is an aunchient lieutenant there at the

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: pridge, I think in my very conscience he is as

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: valiant a man as Mark Antony; and he is a man of no

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: estimation in the world; but did see him do as

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: gallant service.

speaker: GOWER
text_entry: What do you call him?

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: He is called Aunchient Pistol.

speaker: GOWER
text_entry: I know him not.

speaker: GOWER
text_entry: Enter PISTOL

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: Here is the man.

speaker: PISTOL
text_entry: Captain, I thee beseech to do me favours:

speaker: PISTOL
text_entry: The Duke of Exeter doth love thee well.

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: Ay, I praise God; and I have merited some love at

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: his hands.

speaker: PISTOL
text_entry: Bardolph, a soldier, firm and sound of heart,

speaker: PISTOL
text_entry: And of buxom valour, hath, by cruel fate,

speaker: PISTOL
text_entry: And giddy Fortune's furious fickle wheel,

speaker: PISTOL
text_entry: That goddess blind,

speaker: PISTOL
text_entry: That stands upon the rolling restless stone--

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: By your patience, Aunchient Pistol. Fortune is

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: painted blind, with a muffler afore her eyes, to

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: signify to you that Fortune is blind; and she is

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: painted also with a wheel, to signify to you, which

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: is the moral of it, that she is turning, and

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: inconstant, and mutability, and variation: and her

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: foot, look you, is fixed upon a spherical stone,

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: which rolls, and rolls, and rolls: in good truth,

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: the poet makes a most excellent description of it:

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: Fortune is an excellent moral.

speaker: PISTOL
text_entry: Fortune is Bardolph's foe, and frowns on him;

speaker: PISTOL
text_entry: For he hath stolen a pax, and hanged must a' be:

speaker: PISTOL
text_entry: A damned death!

speaker: PISTOL
text_entry: Let gallows gape for dog; let man go free

speaker: PISTOL
text_entry: And let not hemp his wind-pipe suffocate:

speaker: PISTOL
text_entry: But Exeter hath given the doom of death

speaker: PISTOL
text_entry: For pax of little price.

speaker: PISTOL
text_entry: Therefore, go speak: the duke will hear thy voice:

speaker: PISTOL
text_entry: And let not Bardolph's vital thread be cut

speaker: PISTOL
text_entry: With edge of penny cord and vile reproach:

speaker: PISTOL
text_entry: Speak, captain, for his life, and I will thee requite.

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: Aunchient Pistol, I do partly understand your meaning.

speaker: PISTOL
text_entry: Why then, rejoice therefore.

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: Certainly, aunchient, it is not a thing to rejoice

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: at: for if, look you, he were my brother, I would

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: desire the duke to use his good pleasure, and put

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: him to execution; for discipline ought to be used.

speaker: PISTOL
text_entry: Die and be damn'd! and figo for thy friendship!

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: It is well.

speaker: PISTOL
text_entry: The fig of Spain!

speaker: PISTOL
text_entry: Exit

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: Very good.

speaker: GOWER
text_entry: Why, this is an arrant counterfeit rascal; I

speaker: GOWER
text_entry: remember him now; a bawd, a cutpurse.

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: I'll assure you, a' uttered as brave words at the

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: bridge as you shall see in a summer's day. But it

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: is very well; what he has spoke to me, that is well,

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: I warrant you, when time is serve.

speaker: GOWER
text_entry: Why, 'tis a gull, a fool, a rogue, that now and then

speaker: GOWER
text_entry: goes to the wars, to grace himself at his return

speaker: GOWER
text_entry: into London under the form of a soldier. And such

speaker: GOWER
text_entry: fellows are perfect in the great commanders' names:

speaker: GOWER
text_entry: and they will learn you by rote where services were

speaker: GOWER
text_entry: done; at such and such a sconce, at such a breach,

speaker: GOWER
text_entry: at such a convoy; who came off bravely, who was

speaker: GOWER
text_entry: shot, who disgraced, what terms the enemy stood on;

speaker: GOWER
text_entry: and this they con perfectly in the phrase of war,

speaker: GOWER
text_entry: which they trick up with new-tuned oaths: and what

speaker: GOWER
text_entry: a beard of the general's cut and a horrid suit of

speaker: GOWER
text_entry: the camp will do among foaming bottles and

speaker: GOWER
text_entry: ale-washed wits, is wonderful to be thought on. But

speaker: GOWER
text_entry: you must learn to know such slanders of the age, or

speaker: GOWER
text_entry: else you may be marvellously mistook.

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: I tell you what, Captain Gower; I do perceive he is

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: not the man that he would gladly make show to the

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: world he is: if I find a hole in his coat, I will

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: tell him my mind.

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: Drum heard

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: Hark you, the king is coming, and I must speak with

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: him from the pridge.

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: Drum and colours. Enter KING HENRY, GLOUCESTER, and Soldiers

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: God pless your majesty!

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: How now, Fluellen! camest thou from the bridge?

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: Ay, so please your majesty. The Duke of Exeter has

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: very gallantly maintained the pridge: the French is

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: gone off, look you; and there is gallant and most

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: prave passages; marry, th' athversary was have

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: possession of the pridge; but he is enforced to

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: retire, and the Duke of Exeter is master of the

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: pridge: I can tell your majesty, the duke is a

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: prave man.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: What men have you lost, Fluellen?

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: The perdition of th' athversary hath been very

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: great, reasonable great: marry, for my part, I

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: think the duke hath lost never a man, but one that

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: is like to be executed for robbing a church, one

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: Bardolph, if your majesty know the man: his face is

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: all bubukles, and whelks, and knobs, and flames o'

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: fire: and his lips blows at his nose, and it is like

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: a coal of fire, sometimes plue and sometimes red;

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: but his nose is executed and his fire's out.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: We would have all such offenders so cut off: and we

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: give express charge, that in our marches through the

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: country, there be nothing compelled from the

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: villages, nothing taken but paid for, none of the

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: French upbraided or abused in disdainful language;

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: for when lenity and cruelty play for a kingdom, the

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: gentler gamester is the soonest winner.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Tucket. Enter MONTJOY

speaker: MONTJOY
text_entry: You know me by my habit.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Well then I know thee: what shall I know of thee?

speaker: MONTJOY
text_entry: My master's mind.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Unfold it.

speaker: MONTJOY
text_entry: Thus says my king: Say thou to Harry of England:

speaker: MONTJOY
text_entry: Though we seemed dead, we did but sleep: advantage

speaker: MONTJOY
text_entry: is a better soldier than rashness. Tell him we

speaker: MONTJOY
text_entry: could have rebuked him at Harfleur, but that we

speaker: MONTJOY
text_entry: thought not good to bruise an injury till it were

speaker: MONTJOY
text_entry: full ripe: now we speak upon our cue, and our voice

speaker: MONTJOY
text_entry: is imperial: England shall repent his folly, see

speaker: MONTJOY
text_entry: his weakness, and admire our sufferance. Bid him

speaker: MONTJOY
text_entry: therefore consider of his ransom; which must

speaker: MONTJOY
text_entry: proportion the losses we have borne, the subjects we

speaker: MONTJOY
text_entry: have lost, the disgrace we have digested; which in

speaker: MONTJOY
text_entry: weight to re-answer, his pettiness would bow under.

speaker: MONTJOY
text_entry: For our losses, his exchequer is too poor; for the

speaker: MONTJOY
text_entry: effusion of our blood, the muster of his kingdom too

speaker: MONTJOY
text_entry: faint a number; and for our disgrace, his own

speaker: MONTJOY
text_entry: person, kneeling at our feet, but a weak and

speaker: MONTJOY
text_entry: worthless satisfaction. To this add defiance: and

speaker: MONTJOY
text_entry: tell him, for conclusion, he hath betrayed his

speaker: MONTJOY
text_entry: followers, whose condemnation is pronounced. So far

speaker: MONTJOY
text_entry: my king and master; so much my office.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: What is thy name? I know thy quality.

speaker: MONTJOY
text_entry: Montjoy.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Thou dost thy office fairly. Turn thee back.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: And tell thy king I do not seek him now;

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: But could be willing to march on to Calais

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Without impeachment: for, to say the sooth,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Though 'tis no wisdom to confess so much

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Unto an enemy of craft and vantage,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: My people are with sickness much enfeebled,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: My numbers lessened, and those few I have

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Almost no better than so many French;

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Who when they were in health, I tell thee, herald,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: I thought upon one pair of English legs

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Did march three Frenchmen. Yet, forgive me, God,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: That I do brag thus! This your air of France

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Hath blown that vice in me: I must repent.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Go therefore, tell thy master here I am;

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: My ransom is this frail and worthless trunk,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: My army but a weak and sickly guard;

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Yet, God before, tell him we will come on,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Though France himself and such another neighbour

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Stand in our way. There's for thy labour, Montjoy.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Go bid thy master well advise himself:

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: If we may pass, we will; if we be hinder'd,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: We shall your tawny ground with your red blood

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Discolour: and so Montjoy, fare you well.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: The sum of all our answer is but this:

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: We would not seek a battle, as we are;

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Nor, as we are, we say we will not shun it:

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: So tell your master.

speaker: MONTJOY
text_entry: I shall deliver so. Thanks to your highness.

speaker: MONTJOY
text_entry: Exit

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: I hope they will not come upon us now.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: We are in God's hand, brother, not in theirs.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: March to the bridge; it now draws toward night:

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Beyond the river we'll encamp ourselves,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: And on to-morrow, bid them march away.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: SCENE VII. The French camp, near Agincourt:

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Enter the Constable of France, the LORD RAMBURES, ORLEANS, DAUPHIN, with others

speaker: Constable
text_entry: Tut! I have the best armour of the world. Would it were day!

speaker: ORLEANS
text_entry: You have an excellent armour; but let my horse have his due.

speaker: Constable
text_entry: It is the best horse of Europe.

speaker: ORLEANS
text_entry: Will it never be morning?

speaker: DAUPHIN
text_entry: My lord of Orleans, and my lord high constable, you

speaker: DAUPHIN
text_entry: talk of horse and armour?

speaker: ORLEANS
text_entry: You are as well provided of both as any prince in the world.

speaker: DAUPHIN
text_entry: What a long night is this! I will not change my

speaker: DAUPHIN
text_entry: horse with any that treads but on four pasterns.

speaker: DAUPHIN
text_entry: Ca, ha! he bounds from the earth, as if his

speaker: DAUPHIN
text_entry: entrails were hairs; le cheval volant, the Pegasus,

speaker: DAUPHIN
text_entry: chez les narines de feu! When I bestride him, I

speaker: DAUPHIN
text_entry: soar, I am a hawk: he trots the air; the earth

speaker: DAUPHIN
text_entry: sings when he touches it; the basest horn of his

speaker: DAUPHIN
text_entry: hoof is more musical than the pipe of Hermes.

speaker: ORLEANS
text_entry: He's of the colour of the nutmeg.

speaker: DAUPHIN
text_entry: And of the heat of the ginger. It is a beast for

speaker: DAUPHIN
text_entry: Perseus: he is pure air and fire; and the dull

speaker: DAUPHIN
text_entry: elements of earth and water never appear in him, but

speaker: DAUPHIN
text_entry: only in Patient stillness while his rider mounts

speaker: DAUPHIN
text_entry: him: he is indeed a horse; and all other jades you

speaker: DAUPHIN
text_entry: may call beasts.

speaker: Constable
text_entry: Indeed, my lord, it is a most absolute and excellent horse.

speaker: DAUPHIN
text_entry: It is the prince of palfreys; his neigh is like the

speaker: DAUPHIN
text_entry: bidding of a monarch and his countenance enforces homage.

speaker: ORLEANS
text_entry: No more, cousin.

speaker: DAUPHIN
text_entry: Nay, the man hath no wit that cannot, from the

speaker: DAUPHIN
text_entry: rising of the lark to the lodging of the lamb, vary

speaker: DAUPHIN
text_entry: deserved praise on my palfrey: it is a theme as

speaker: DAUPHIN
text_entry: fluent as the sea: turn the sands into eloquent

speaker: DAUPHIN
text_entry: tongues, and my horse is argument for them all:

speaker: DAUPHIN
text_entry: 'tis a subject for a sovereign to reason on, and for

speaker: DAUPHIN
text_entry: a sovereign's sovereign to ride on; and for the

speaker: DAUPHIN
text_entry: world, familiar to us and unknown to lay apart

speaker: DAUPHIN
text_entry: their particular functions and wonder at him. I

speaker: DAUPHIN
text_entry: once writ a sonnet in his praise and began thus:

speaker: DAUPHIN
text_entry: 'Wonder of nature,'--

speaker: ORLEANS
text_entry: I have heard a sonnet begin so to one's mistress.

speaker: DAUPHIN
text_entry: Then did they imitate that which I composed to my

speaker: DAUPHIN
text_entry: courser, for my horse is my mistress.

speaker: ORLEANS
text_entry: Your mistress bears well.

speaker: DAUPHIN
text_entry: Me well; which is the prescript praise and

speaker: DAUPHIN
text_entry: perfection of a good and particular mistress.

speaker: Constable
text_entry: Nay, for methought yesterday your mistress shrewdly

speaker: Constable
text_entry: shook your back.

speaker: DAUPHIN
text_entry: So perhaps did yours.

speaker: Constable
text_entry: Mine was not bridled.

speaker: DAUPHIN
text_entry: O then belike she was old and gentle; and you rode,

speaker: DAUPHIN
text_entry: like a kern of Ireland, your French hose off, and in

speaker: DAUPHIN
text_entry: your straight strossers.

speaker: Constable
text_entry: You have good judgment in horsemanship.

speaker: DAUPHIN
text_entry: Be warned by me, then: they that ride so and ride

speaker: DAUPHIN
text_entry: not warily, fall into foul bogs. I had rather have

speaker: DAUPHIN
text_entry: my horse to my mistress.

speaker: Constable
text_entry: I had as lief have my mistress a jade.

speaker: DAUPHIN
text_entry: I tell thee, constable, my mistress wears his own hair.

speaker: Constable
text_entry: I could make as true a boast as that, if I had a sow

speaker: Constable
text_entry: to my mistress.

speaker: DAUPHIN
text_entry: 'Le chien est retourne a son propre vomissement, et

speaker: DAUPHIN
text_entry: la truie lavee au bourbier;' thou makest use of any thing.

speaker: Constable
text_entry: Yet do I not use my horse for my mistress, or any

speaker: Constable
text_entry: such proverb so little kin to the purpose.

speaker: RAMBURES
text_entry: My lord constable, the armour that I saw in your tent

speaker: RAMBURES
text_entry: to-night, are those stars or suns upon it?

speaker: Constable
text_entry: Stars, my lord.

speaker: DAUPHIN
text_entry: Some of them will fall to-morrow, I hope.

speaker: Constable
text_entry: And yet my sky shall not want.

speaker: DAUPHIN
text_entry: That may be, for you bear a many superfluously, and

speaker: DAUPHIN
text_entry: 'twere more honour some were away.

speaker: Constable
text_entry: Even as your horse bears your praises; who would

speaker: Constable
text_entry: trot as well, were some of your brags dismounted.

speaker: DAUPHIN
text_entry: Would I were able to load him with his desert! Will

speaker: DAUPHIN
text_entry: it never be day? I will trot to-morrow a mile, and

speaker: DAUPHIN
text_entry: my way shall be paved with English faces.

speaker: Constable
text_entry: I will not say so, for fear I should be faced out of

speaker: Constable
text_entry: my way: but I would it were morning; for I would

speaker: Constable
text_entry: fain be about the ears of the English.

speaker: RAMBURES
text_entry: Who will go to hazard with me for twenty prisoners?

speaker: Constable
text_entry: You must first go yourself to hazard, ere you have them.

speaker: DAUPHIN
text_entry: 'Tis midnight; I'll go arm myself.

speaker: DAUPHIN
text_entry: Exit

speaker: ORLEANS
text_entry: The Dauphin longs for morning.
