speaker: RAMBURES
text_entry: He longs to eat the English.

speaker: Constable
text_entry: I think he will eat all he kills.

speaker: ORLEANS
text_entry: By the white hand of my lady, he's a gallant prince.

speaker: Constable
text_entry: Swear by her foot, that she may tread out the oath.

speaker: ORLEANS
text_entry: He is simply the most active gentleman of France.

speaker: Constable
text_entry: Doing is activity; and he will still be doing.

speaker: ORLEANS
text_entry: He never did harm, that I heard of.

speaker: Constable
text_entry: Nor will do none to-morrow: he will keep that good name still.

speaker: ORLEANS
text_entry: I know him to be valiant.

speaker: Constable
text_entry: I was told that  by one that knows him better than

speaker: Constable
text_entry: you.

speaker: ORLEANS
text_entry: What's he?

speaker: Constable
text_entry: Marry, he told me so himself; and he said he cared

speaker: Constable
text_entry: not who knew it

speaker: ORLEANS
text_entry: He needs not; it is no hidden virtue in him.

speaker: Constable
text_entry: By my faith, sir, but it is; never any body saw it

speaker: Constable
text_entry: but his lackey: 'tis a hooded valour; and when it

speaker: Constable
text_entry: appears, it will bate.

speaker: ORLEANS
text_entry: Ill will never said well.

speaker: Constable
text_entry: I will cap that proverb with 'There is flattery in friendship.'

speaker: ORLEANS
text_entry: And I will take up that with 'Give the devil his due.'

speaker: Constable
text_entry: Well placed: there stands your friend for the

speaker: Constable
text_entry: devil: have at the very eye of that proverb with 'A

speaker: Constable
text_entry: pox of the devil.'

speaker: ORLEANS
text_entry: You are the better at proverbs, by how much 'A

speaker: ORLEANS
text_entry: fool's bolt is soon shot.'

speaker: Constable
text_entry: You have shot over.

speaker: ORLEANS
text_entry: 'Tis not the first time you were overshot.

speaker: ORLEANS
text_entry: Enter a Messenger

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: My lord high constable, the English lie within

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: fifteen hundred paces of your tents.

speaker: Constable
text_entry: Who hath measured the ground?

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: The Lord Grandpre.

speaker: Constable
text_entry: A valiant and most expert gentleman. Would it were

speaker: Constable
text_entry: day! Alas, poor Harry of England! he longs not for

speaker: Constable
text_entry: the dawning as we do.

speaker: ORLEANS
text_entry: What a wretched and peevish fellow is this king of

speaker: ORLEANS
text_entry: England, to mope with his fat-brained followers so

speaker: ORLEANS
text_entry: far out of his knowledge!

speaker: Constable
text_entry: If the English had any apprehension, they would run away.

speaker: ORLEANS
text_entry: That they lack; for if their heads had any

speaker: ORLEANS
text_entry: intellectual armour, they could never wear such heavy

speaker: ORLEANS
text_entry: head-pieces.

speaker: RAMBURES
text_entry: That island of England breeds very valiant

speaker: RAMBURES
text_entry: creatures; their mastiffs are of unmatchable courage.

speaker: ORLEANS
text_entry: Foolish curs, that run winking into the mouth of a

speaker: ORLEANS
text_entry: Russian bear and have their heads crushed like

speaker: ORLEANS
text_entry: rotten apples! You may as well say, that's a

speaker: ORLEANS
text_entry: valiant flea that dare eat his breakfast on the lip of a lion.

speaker: Constable
text_entry: Just, just; and the men do sympathize with the

speaker: Constable
text_entry: mastiffs in robustious and rough coming on, leaving

speaker: Constable
text_entry: their wits with their wives: and then give them

speaker: Constable
text_entry: great meals of beef and iron and steel, they will

speaker: Constable
text_entry: eat like wolves and fight like devils.

speaker: ORLEANS
text_entry: Ay, but these English are shrewdly out of beef.

speaker: Constable
text_entry: Then shall we find to-morrow they have only stomachs

speaker: Constable
text_entry: to eat and none to fight. Now is it time to arm:

speaker: Constable
text_entry: come, shall we about it?

speaker: ORLEANS
text_entry: It is now two o'clock: but, let me see, by ten

speaker: ORLEANS
text_entry: We shall have each a hundred Englishmen.

speaker: ORLEANS
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: ORLEANS
text_entry: ACT IV

speaker: ORLEANS
text_entry: PROLOGUE

speaker: ORLEANS
text_entry: Enter Chorus

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: Now entertain conjecture of a time

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: When creeping murmur and the poring dark

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: Fills the wide vessel of the universe.

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: From camp to camp through the foul womb of night

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: The hum of either army stilly sounds,

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: That the fixed sentinels almost receive

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: The secret whispers of each other's watch:

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: Fire answers fire, and through their paly flames

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: Each battle sees the other's umber'd face;

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: Steed threatens steed, in high and boastful neighs

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: Piercing the night's dull ear, and from the tents

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: The armourers, accomplishing the knights,

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: With busy hammers closing rivets up,

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: Give dreadful note of preparation:

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: The country cocks do crow, the clocks do toll,

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: And the third hour of drowsy morning name.

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: Proud of their numbers and secure in soul,

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: The confident and over-lusty French

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: Do the low-rated English play at dice;

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: And chide the cripple tardy-gaited night

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: Who, like a foul and ugly witch, doth limp

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: So tediously away. The poor condemned English,

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: Like sacrifices, by their watchful fires

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: Sit patiently and inly ruminate

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: The morning's danger, and their gesture sad

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: Investing lank-lean; cheeks and war-worn coats

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: Presenteth them unto the gazing moon

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: So many horrid ghosts. O now, who will behold

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: The royal captain of this ruin'd band

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: Walking from watch to watch, from tent to tent,

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: Let him cry 'Praise and glory on his head!'

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: For forth he goes and visits all his host.

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: Bids them good morrow with a modest smile

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: And calls them brothers, friends and countrymen.

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: Upon his royal face there is no note

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: How dread an army hath enrounded him;

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: Nor doth he dedicate one jot of colour

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: Unto the weary and all-watched night,

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: But freshly looks and over-bears attaint

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: With cheerful semblance and sweet majesty;

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: That every wretch, pining and pale before,

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: Beholding him, plucks comfort from his looks:

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: A largess universal like the sun

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: His liberal eye doth give to every one,

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: Thawing cold fear, that mean and gentle all,

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: Behold, as may unworthiness define,

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: A little touch of Harry in the night.

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: And so our scene must to the battle fly;

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: Where--O for pity!--we shall much disgrace

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: With four or five most vile and ragged foils,

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: Right ill-disposed in brawl ridiculous,

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: The name of Agincourt. Yet sit and see,

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: Minding true things by what their mockeries be.

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: Exit

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: SCENE I. The English camp at Agincourt.

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: Enter KING HENRY, BEDFORD, and GLOUCESTER

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Gloucester, 'tis true that we are in great danger;

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: The greater therefore should our courage be.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Good morrow, brother Bedford. God Almighty!

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: There is some soul of goodness in things evil,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Would men observingly distil it out.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: For our bad neighbour makes us early stirrers,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Which is both healthful and good husbandry:

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Besides, they are our outward consciences,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: And preachers to us all, admonishing

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: That we should dress us fairly for our end.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Thus may we gather honey from the weed,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: And make a moral of the devil himself.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Enter ERPINGHAM

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Good morrow, old Sir Thomas Erpingham:

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: A good soft pillow for that good white head

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Were better than a churlish turf of France.

speaker: ERPINGHAM
text_entry: Not so, my liege: this lodging likes me better,

speaker: ERPINGHAM
text_entry: Since I may say 'Now lie I like a king.'

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: 'Tis good for men to love their present pains

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Upon example; so the spirit is eased:

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: And when the mind is quicken'd, out of doubt,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: The organs, though defunct and dead before,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Break up their drowsy grave and newly move,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: With casted slough and fresh legerity.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Lend me thy cloak, Sir Thomas. Brothers both,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Commend me to the princes in our camp;

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Do my good morrow to them, and anon

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Desire them an to my pavilion.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: We shall, my liege.

speaker: ERPINGHAM
text_entry: Shall I attend your grace?

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: No, my good knight;

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Go with my brothers to my lords of England:

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: I and my bosom must debate awhile,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: And then I would no other company.

speaker: ERPINGHAM
text_entry: The Lord in heaven bless thee, noble Harry!

speaker: ERPINGHAM
text_entry: Exeunt all but KING HENRY

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: God-a-mercy, old heart! thou speak'st cheerfully.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Enter PISTOL

speaker: PISTOL
text_entry: Qui va la?

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: A friend.

speaker: PISTOL
text_entry: Discuss unto me; art thou officer?

speaker: PISTOL
text_entry: Or art thou base, common and popular?

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: I am a gentleman of a company.

speaker: PISTOL
text_entry: Trail'st thou the puissant pike?

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Even so. What are you?

speaker: PISTOL
text_entry: As good a gentleman as the emperor.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Then you are a better than the king.

speaker: PISTOL
text_entry: The king's a bawcock, and a heart of gold,

speaker: PISTOL
text_entry: A lad of life, an imp of fame;

speaker: PISTOL
text_entry: Of parents good, of fist most valiant.

speaker: PISTOL
text_entry: I kiss his dirty shoe, and from heart-string

speaker: PISTOL
text_entry: I love the lovely bully. What is thy name?

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Harry le Roy.

speaker: PISTOL
text_entry: Le Roy! a Cornish name: art thou of Cornish crew?

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: No, I am a Welshman.

speaker: PISTOL
text_entry: Know'st thou Fluellen?

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Yes.

speaker: PISTOL
text_entry: Tell him, I'll knock his leek about his pate

speaker: PISTOL
text_entry: Upon Saint Davy's day.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Do not you wear your dagger in your cap that day,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: lest he knock that about yours.

speaker: PISTOL
text_entry: Art thou his friend?

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: And his kinsman too.

speaker: PISTOL
text_entry: The figo for thee, then!

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: I thank you: God be with you!

speaker: PISTOL
text_entry: My name is Pistol call'd.

speaker: PISTOL
text_entry: Exit

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: It sorts well with your fierceness.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Enter FLUELLEN and GOWER

speaker: GOWER
text_entry: Captain Fluellen!

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: So! in the name of Jesu Christ, speak lower. It is

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: the greatest admiration of the universal world, when

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: the true and aunchient prerogatifes and laws of the

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: wars is not kept: if you would take the pains but to

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: examine the wars of Pompey the Great, you shall

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: find, I warrant you, that there is no tiddle toddle

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: nor pibble pabble in Pompey's camp; I warrant you,

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: you shall find the ceremonies of the wars, and the

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: cares of it, and the forms of it, and the sobriety

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: of it, and the modesty of it, to be otherwise.

speaker: GOWER
text_entry: Why, the enemy is loud; you hear him all night.

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: If the enemy is an ass and a fool and a prating

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: coxcomb, is it meet, think you, that we should also,

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: look you, be an ass and a fool and a prating

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: coxcomb? in your own conscience, now?

speaker: GOWER
text_entry: I will speak lower.

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: I pray you and beseech you that you will.

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: Exeunt GOWER and FLUELLEN

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Though it appear a little out of fashion,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: There is much care and valour in this Welshman.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Enter three soldiers, JOHN BATES, ALEXANDER COURT, and MICHAEL WILLIAMS

speaker: COURT
text_entry: Brother John Bates, is not that the morning which

speaker: COURT
text_entry: breaks yonder?

speaker: BATES
text_entry: I think it be: but we have no great cause to desire

speaker: BATES
text_entry: the approach of day.

speaker: WILLIAMS
text_entry: We see yonder the beginning of the day, but I think

speaker: WILLIAMS
text_entry: we shall never see the end of it. Who goes there?

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: A friend.

speaker: WILLIAMS
text_entry: Under what captain serve you?

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Under Sir Thomas Erpingham.

speaker: WILLIAMS
text_entry: A good old commander and a most kind gentleman: I

speaker: WILLIAMS
text_entry: pray you, what thinks he of our estate?

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Even as men wrecked upon a sand, that look to be

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: washed off the next tide.

speaker: BATES
text_entry: He hath not told his thought to the king?

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: No; nor it is not meet he should. For, though I

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: speak it to you, I think the king is but a man, as I

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: am: the violet smells to him as it doth to me: the

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: element shows to him as it doth to me; all his

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: senses have but human conditions: his ceremonies

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: laid by, in his nakedness he appears but a man; and

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: though his affections are higher mounted than ours,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: yet, when they stoop, they stoop with the like

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: wing. Therefore when he sees reason of fears, as we

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: do, his fears, out of doubt, be of the same relish

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: as ours are: yet, in reason, no man should possess

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: him with any appearance of fear, lest he, by showing

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: it, should dishearten his army.

speaker: BATES
text_entry: He may show what outward courage he will; but I

speaker: BATES
text_entry: believe, as cold a night as 'tis, he could wish

speaker: BATES
text_entry: himself in Thames up to the neck; and so I would he

speaker: BATES
text_entry: were, and I by him, at all adventures, so we were quit here.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: By my troth, I will speak my conscience of the king:

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: I think he would not wish himself any where but

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: where he is.

speaker: BATES
text_entry: Then I would he were here alone; so should he be

speaker: BATES
text_entry: sure to be ransomed, and a many poor men's lives saved.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: I dare say you love him not so ill, to wish him here

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: alone, howsoever you speak this to feel other men's

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: minds: methinks I could not die any where so

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: contented as in the king's company; his cause being

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: just and his quarrel honourable.

speaker: WILLIAMS
text_entry: That's more than we know.

speaker: BATES
text_entry: Ay, or more than we should seek after; for we know

speaker: BATES
text_entry: enough, if we know we are the kings subjects: if

speaker: BATES
text_entry: his cause be wrong, our obedience to the king wipes

speaker: BATES
text_entry: the crime of it out of us.

speaker: WILLIAMS
text_entry: But if the cause be not good, the king himself hath

speaker: WILLIAMS
text_entry: a heavy reckoning to make, when all those legs and

speaker: WILLIAMS
text_entry: arms and heads, chopped off in battle, shall join

speaker: WILLIAMS
text_entry: together at the latter day and cry all 'We died at

speaker: WILLIAMS
text_entry: such a place;' some swearing, some crying for a

speaker: WILLIAMS
text_entry: surgeon, some upon their wives left poor behind

speaker: WILLIAMS
text_entry: them, some upon the debts they owe, some upon their

speaker: WILLIAMS
text_entry: children rawly left. I am afeard there are few die

speaker: WILLIAMS
text_entry: well that die in a battle; for how can they

speaker: WILLIAMS
text_entry: charitably dispose of any thing, when blood is their

speaker: WILLIAMS
text_entry: argument? Now, if these men do not die well, it

speaker: WILLIAMS
text_entry: will be a black matter for the king that led them to

speaker: WILLIAMS
text_entry: it; whom to disobey were against all proportion of

speaker: WILLIAMS
text_entry: subjection.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: So, if a son that is by his father sent about

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: merchandise do sinfully miscarry upon the sea, the

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: imputation of his wickedness by your rule, should be

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: imposed upon his father that sent him: or if a

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: servant, under his master's command transporting a

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: sum of money, be assailed by robbers and die in

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: many irreconciled iniquities, you may call the

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: business of the master the author of the servant's

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: damnation: but this is not so: the king is not

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: bound to answer the particular endings of his

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: soldiers, the father of his son, nor the master of

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: his servant; for they purpose not their death, when

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: they purpose their services. Besides, there is no

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: king, be his cause never so spotless, if it come to

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: the arbitrement of swords, can try it out with all

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: unspotted soldiers: some peradventure have on them

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: the guilt of premeditated and contrived murder;

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: some, of beguiling virgins with the broken seals of

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: perjury; some, making the wars their bulwark, that

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: have before gored the gentle bosom of peace with

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: pillage and robbery. Now, if these men have

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: defeated the law and outrun native punishment,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: though they can outstrip men, they have no wings to

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: fly from God: war is his beadle, war is vengeance;

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: so that here men are punished for before-breach of

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: the king's laws in now the king's quarrel: where

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: they feared the death, they have borne life away;

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: and where they would be safe, they perish: then if

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: they die unprovided, no more is the king guilty of

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: their damnation than he was before guilty of those

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: impieties for the which they are now visited. Every

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: subject's duty is the king's; but every subject's

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: soul is his own. Therefore should every soldier in

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: the wars do as every sick man in his bed, wash every

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: mote out of his conscience: and dying so, death

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: is to him advantage; or not dying, the time was

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: blessedly lost wherein such preparation was gained:

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: and in him that escapes, it were not sin to think

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: that, making God so free an offer, He let him

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: outlive that day to see His greatness and to teach

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: others how they should prepare.

speaker: WILLIAMS
text_entry: 'Tis certain, every man that dies ill, the ill upon

speaker: WILLIAMS
text_entry: his own head, the king is not to answer it.

speaker: BATES
text_entry: But I do not desire he should answer for me; and

speaker: BATES
text_entry: yet I determine to fight lustily for him.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: I myself heard the king say he would not be ransomed.

speaker: WILLIAMS
text_entry: Ay, he said so, to make us fight cheerfully: but

speaker: WILLIAMS
text_entry: when our throats are cut, he may be ransomed, and we

speaker: WILLIAMS
text_entry: ne'er the wiser.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: If I live to see it, I will never trust his word after.

speaker: WILLIAMS
text_entry: You pay him then. That's a perilous shot out of an

speaker: WILLIAMS
text_entry: elder-gun, that a poor and private displeasure can

speaker: WILLIAMS
text_entry: do against a monarch! you may as well go about to

speaker: WILLIAMS
text_entry: turn the sun to ice with fanning in his face with a

speaker: WILLIAMS
text_entry: peacock's feather. You'll never trust his word

speaker: WILLIAMS
text_entry: after! come, 'tis a foolish saying.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Your reproof is something too round: I should be

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: angry with you, if the time were convenient.

speaker: WILLIAMS
text_entry: Let it be a quarrel between us, if you live.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: I embrace it.

speaker: WILLIAMS
text_entry: How shall I know thee again?

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Give me any gage of thine, and I will wear it in my

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: bonnet: then, if ever thou darest acknowledge it, I

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: will make it my quarrel.

speaker: WILLIAMS
text_entry: Here's my glove: give me another of thine.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: There.

speaker: WILLIAMS
text_entry: This will I also wear in my cap: if ever thou come

speaker: WILLIAMS
text_entry: to me and say, after to-morrow, 'This is my glove,'

speaker: WILLIAMS
text_entry: by this hand, I will take thee a box on the ear.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: If ever I live to see it, I will challenge it.

speaker: WILLIAMS
text_entry: Thou darest as well be hanged.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Well. I will do it, though I take thee in the

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: king's company.

speaker: WILLIAMS
text_entry: Keep thy word: fare thee well.

speaker: BATES
text_entry: Be friends, you English fools, be friends: we have

speaker: BATES
text_entry: French quarrels enow, if you could tell how to reckon.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Indeed, the French may lay twenty French crowns to

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: one, they will beat us; for they bear them on their

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: shoulders: but it is no English treason to cut

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: French crowns, and to-morrow the king himself will

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: be a clipper.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Exeunt soldiers

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Upon the king! let us our lives, our souls,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Our debts, our careful wives,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Our children and our sins lay on the king!

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: We must bear all. O hard condition,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Twin-born with greatness, subject to the breath

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Of every fool, whose sense no more can feel

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: But his own wringing! What infinite heart's-ease

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Must kings neglect, that private men enjoy!

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: And what have kings, that privates have not too,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Save ceremony, save general ceremony?

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: And what art thou, thou idle ceremony?

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: What kind of god art thou, that suffer'st more

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Of mortal griefs than do thy worshippers?

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: What are thy rents? what are thy comings in?

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: O ceremony, show me but thy worth!

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: What is thy soul of adoration?

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Art thou aught else but place, degree and form,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Creating awe and fear in other men?

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Wherein thou art less happy being fear'd

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Than they in fearing.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: What drink'st thou oft, instead of homage sweet,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: But poison'd flattery? O, be sick, great greatness,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: And bid thy ceremony give thee cure!

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Think'st thou the fiery fever will go out

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: With titles blown from adulation?

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Will it give place to flexure and low bending?

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Canst thou, when thou command'st the beggar's knee,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Command the health of it? No, thou proud dream,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: That play'st so subtly with a king's repose;

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: I am a king that find thee, and I know

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: 'Tis not the balm, the sceptre and the ball,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: The sword, the mace, the crown imperial,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: The intertissued robe of gold and pearl,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: The farced title running 'fore the king,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: The throne he sits on, nor the tide of pomp

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: That beats upon the high shore of this world,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: No, not all these, thrice-gorgeous ceremony,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Not all these, laid in bed majestical,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Can sleep so soundly as the wretched slave,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Who with a body fill'd and vacant mind

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Gets him to rest, cramm'd with distressful bread;

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Never sees horrid night, the child of hell,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: But, like a lackey, from the rise to set

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Sweats in the eye of Phoebus and all night

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Sleeps in Elysium; next day after dawn,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Doth rise and help Hyperion to his horse,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: And follows so the ever-running year,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: With profitable labour, to his grave:

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: And, but for ceremony, such a wretch,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Winding up days with toil and nights with sleep,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Had the fore-hand and vantage of a king.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: The slave, a member of the country's peace,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Enjoys it; but in gross brain little wots

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: What watch the king keeps to maintain the peace,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Whose hours the peasant best advantages.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Enter ERPINGHAM

speaker: ERPINGHAM
text_entry: My lord, your nobles, jealous of your absence,

speaker: ERPINGHAM
text_entry: Seek through your camp to find you.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Good old knight,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Collect them all together at my tent:

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: I'll be before thee.

speaker: ERPINGHAM
text_entry: I shall do't, my lord.

speaker: ERPINGHAM
text_entry: Exit

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: O God of battles! steel my soldiers' hearts;

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Possess them not with fear; take from them now

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: The sense of reckoning, if the opposed numbers

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Pluck their hearts from them. Not to-day, O Lord,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: O, not to-day, think not upon the fault

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: My father made in compassing the crown!

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: I Richard's body have interred anew;

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: And on it have bestow'd more contrite tears

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Than from it issued forced drops of blood:

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Five hundred poor I have in yearly pay,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Who twice a-day their wither'd hands hold up

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Toward heaven, to pardon blood; and I have built

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Two chantries, where the sad and solemn priests

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Sing still for Richard's soul. More will I do;

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Though all that I can do is nothing worth,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Since that my penitence comes after all,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Imploring pardon.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Enter GLOUCESTER

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: My liege!

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: My brother Gloucester's voice? Ay;

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: I know thy errand, I will go with thee:

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: The day, my friends and all things stay for me.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: SCENE II. The French camp.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Enter the DAUPHIN, ORLEANS, RAMBURES, and others

speaker: ORLEANS
text_entry: The sun doth gild our armour; up, my lords!

speaker: DAUPHIN
text_entry: Montez A cheval! My horse! varlet! laquais! ha!

speaker: ORLEANS
text_entry: O brave spirit!

speaker: DAUPHIN
text_entry: Via! les eaux et la terre.

speaker: ORLEANS
text_entry: Rien puis? L'air et la feu.

speaker: DAUPHIN
text_entry: Ciel, cousin Orleans.

speaker: DAUPHIN
text_entry: Enter Constable

speaker: DAUPHIN
text_entry: Now, my lord constable!

speaker: Constable
text_entry: Hark, how our steeds for present service neigh!

speaker: DAUPHIN
text_entry: Mount them, and make incision in their hides,

speaker: DAUPHIN
text_entry: That their hot blood may spin in English eyes,

speaker: DAUPHIN
text_entry: And dout them with superfluous courage, ha!

speaker: RAMBURES
text_entry: What, will you have them weep our horses' blood?

speaker: RAMBURES
text_entry: How shall we, then, behold their natural tears?

speaker: RAMBURES
text_entry: Enter Messenger

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: The English are embattled, you French peers.

speaker: Constable
text_entry: To horse, you gallant princes! straight to horse!

speaker: Constable
text_entry: Do but behold yon poor and starved band,

speaker: Constable
text_entry: And your fair show shall suck away their souls,

speaker: Constable
text_entry: Leaving them but the shales and husks of men.

speaker: Constable
text_entry: There is not work enough for all our hands;

speaker: Constable
text_entry: Scarce blood enough in all their sickly veins

speaker: Constable
text_entry: To give each naked curtle-axe a stain,

speaker: Constable
text_entry: That our French gallants shall to-day draw out,

speaker: Constable
text_entry: And sheathe for lack of sport: let us but blow on them,

speaker: Constable
text_entry: The vapour of our valour will o'erturn them.

speaker: Constable
text_entry: 'Tis positive 'gainst all exceptions, lords,

speaker: Constable
text_entry: That our superfluous lackeys and our peasants,

speaker: Constable
text_entry: Who in unnecessary action swarm

speaker: Constable
text_entry: About our squares of battle, were enow

speaker: Constable
text_entry: To purge this field of such a hilding foe,

speaker: Constable
text_entry: Though we upon this mountain's basis by

speaker: Constable
text_entry: Took stand for idle speculation:

speaker: Constable
text_entry: But that our honours must not. What's to say?

speaker: Constable
text_entry: A very little little let us do.

speaker: Constable
text_entry: And all is done. Then let the trumpets sound

speaker: Constable
text_entry: The tucket sonance and the note to mount;

speaker: Constable
text_entry: For our approach shall so much dare the field

speaker: Constable
text_entry: That England shall couch down in fear and yield.

speaker: Constable
text_entry: Enter GRANDPRE

speaker: GRANDPRE
text_entry: Why do you stay so long, my lords of France?

speaker: GRANDPRE
text_entry: Yon island carrions, desperate of their bones,

speaker: GRANDPRE
text_entry: Ill-favouredly become the morning field:

speaker: GRANDPRE
text_entry: Their ragged curtains poorly are let loose,

speaker: GRANDPRE
text_entry: And our air shakes them passing scornfully:

speaker: GRANDPRE
text_entry: Big Mars seems bankrupt in their beggar'd host

speaker: GRANDPRE
text_entry: And faintly through a rusty beaver peeps:

speaker: GRANDPRE
text_entry: The horsemen sit like fixed candlesticks,

speaker: GRANDPRE
text_entry: With torch-staves in their hand; and their poor jades

speaker: GRANDPRE
text_entry: Lob down their heads, dropping the hides and hips,

speaker: GRANDPRE
text_entry: The gum down-roping from their pale-dead eyes

speaker: GRANDPRE
text_entry: And in their pale dull mouths the gimmal bit

speaker: GRANDPRE
text_entry: Lies foul with chew'd grass, still and motionless;

speaker: GRANDPRE
text_entry: And their executors, the knavish crows,

speaker: GRANDPRE
text_entry: Fly o'er them, all impatient for their hour.

speaker: GRANDPRE
text_entry: Description cannot suit itself in words

speaker: GRANDPRE
text_entry: To demonstrate the life of such a battle

speaker: GRANDPRE
text_entry: In life so lifeless as it shows itself.

speaker: Constable
text_entry: They have said their prayers, and they stay for death.

speaker: DAUPHIN
text_entry: Shall we go send them dinners and fresh suits

speaker: DAUPHIN
text_entry: And give their fasting horses provender,

speaker: DAUPHIN
text_entry: And after fight with them?

speaker: Constable
text_entry: I stay but for my guidon: to the field!

speaker: Constable
text_entry: I will the banner from a trumpet take,

speaker: Constable
text_entry: And use it for my haste. Come, come, away!

speaker: Constable
text_entry: The sun is high, and we outwear the day.

speaker: Constable
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: Constable
text_entry: SCENE III. The English camp.

speaker: Constable
text_entry: Enter GLOUCESTER, BEDFORD, EXETER, ERPINGHAM, with all his host: SALISBURY and WESTMORELAND

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Where is the king?

speaker: BEDFORD
text_entry: The king himself is rode to view their battle.

speaker: WESTMORELAND
text_entry: Of fighting men they have full three score thousand.

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: There's five to one; besides, they all are fresh.

speaker: SALISBURY
text_entry: God's arm strike with us! 'tis a fearful odds.

speaker: SALISBURY
text_entry: God be wi' you, princes all; I'll to my charge:

speaker: SALISBURY
text_entry: If we no more meet till we meet in heaven,

speaker: SALISBURY
text_entry: Then, joyfully, my noble Lord of Bedford,

speaker: SALISBURY
text_entry: My dear Lord Gloucester, and my good Lord Exeter,

speaker: SALISBURY
text_entry: And my kind kinsman, warriors all, adieu!

speaker: BEDFORD
text_entry: Farewell, good Salisbury; and good luck go with thee!

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: Farewell, kind lord; fight valiantly to-day:

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: And yet I do thee wrong to mind thee of it,

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: For thou art framed of the firm truth of valour.

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: Exit SALISBURY

speaker: BEDFORD
text_entry: He is full of valour as of kindness;

speaker: BEDFORD
text_entry: Princely in both.

speaker: BEDFORD
text_entry: Enter the KING

speaker: WESTMORELAND
text_entry: O that we now had here

speaker: WESTMORELAND
text_entry: But one ten thousand of those men in England

speaker: WESTMORELAND
text_entry: That do no work to-day!

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: What's he that wishes so?

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: My cousin Westmoreland? No, my fair cousin:

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: If we are mark'd to die, we are enow

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: To do our country loss; and if to live,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: The fewer men, the greater share of honour.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: God's will! I pray thee, wish not one man more.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: By Jove, I am not covetous for gold,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Nor care I who doth feed upon my cost;

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: It yearns me not if men my garments wear;

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Such outward things dwell not in my desires:

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: But if it be a sin to covet honour,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: I am the most offending soul alive.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: No, faith, my coz, wish not a man from England:

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: God's peace! I would not lose so great an honour

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: As one man more, methinks, would share from me

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: For the best hope I have. O, do not wish one more!

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Rather proclaim it, Westmoreland, through my host,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: That he which hath no stomach to this fight,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Let him depart; his passport shall be made

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: And crowns for convoy put into his purse:

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: We would not die in that man's company

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: That fears his fellowship to die with us.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: This day is called the feast of Crispian:

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: He that outlives this day, and comes safe home,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Will stand a tip-toe when the day is named,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: And rouse him at the name of Crispian.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: He that shall live this day, and see old age,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Will yearly on the vigil feast his neighbours,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: And say 'To-morrow is Saint Crispian:'

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Then will he strip his sleeve and show his scars.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: And say 'These wounds I had on Crispin's day.'

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Old men forget: yet all shall be forgot,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: But he'll remember with advantages

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: What feats he did that day: then shall our names.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Familiar in his mouth as household words

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Harry the king, Bedford and Exeter,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Warwick and Talbot, Salisbury and Gloucester,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Be in their flowing cups freshly remember'd.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: This story shall the good man teach his son;

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: And Crispin Crispian shall ne'er go by,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: From this day to the ending of the world,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: But we in it shall be remember'd;

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: We few, we happy few, we band of brothers;

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: For he to-day that sheds his blood with me

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Shall be my brother; be he ne'er so vile,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: This day shall gentle his condition:

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: And gentlemen in England now a-bed

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Shall think themselves accursed they were not here,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: And hold their manhoods cheap whiles any speaks

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: That fought with us upon Saint Crispin's day.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Re-enter SALISBURY

speaker: SALISBURY
text_entry: My sovereign lord, bestow yourself with speed:

speaker: SALISBURY
text_entry: The French are bravely in their battles set,

speaker: SALISBURY
text_entry: And will with all expedience charge on us.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: All things are ready, if our minds be so.

speaker: WESTMORELAND
text_entry: Perish the man whose mind is backward now!

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Thou dost not wish more help from England, coz?

speaker: WESTMORELAND
text_entry: God's will! my liege, would you and I alone,

speaker: WESTMORELAND
text_entry: Without more help, could fight this royal battle!

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Why, now thou hast unwish'd five thousand men;

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Which likes me better than to wish us one.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: You know your places: God be with you all!

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Tucket. Enter MONTJOY

speaker: MONTJOY
text_entry: Once more I come to know of thee, King Harry,

speaker: MONTJOY
text_entry: If for thy ransom thou wilt now compound,

speaker: MONTJOY
text_entry: Before thy most assured overthrow:

speaker: MONTJOY
text_entry: For certainly thou art so near the gulf,

speaker: MONTJOY
text_entry: Thou needs must be englutted. Besides, in mercy,

speaker: MONTJOY
text_entry: The constable desires thee thou wilt mind

speaker: MONTJOY
text_entry: Thy followers of repentance; that their souls

speaker: MONTJOY
text_entry: May make a peaceful and a sweet retire

speaker: MONTJOY
text_entry: From off these fields, where, wretches, their poor bodies

speaker: MONTJOY
text_entry: Must lie and fester.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Who hath sent thee now?

speaker: MONTJOY
text_entry: The Constable of France.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: I pray thee, bear my former answer back:

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Bid them achieve me and then sell my bones.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Good God! why should they mock poor fellows thus?

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: The man that once did sell the lion's skin

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: While the beast lived, was killed with hunting him.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: A many of our bodies shall no doubt

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Find native graves; upon the which, I trust,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Shall witness live in brass of this day's work:

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: And those that leave their valiant bones in France,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Dying like men, though buried in your dunghills,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: They shall be famed; for there the sun shall greet them,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: And draw their honours reeking up to heaven;

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Leaving their earthly parts to choke your clime,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: The smell whereof shall breed a plague in France.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Mark then abounding valour in our English,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: That being dead, like to the bullet's grazing,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Break out into a second course of mischief,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Killing in relapse of mortality.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Let me speak proudly: tell the constable

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: We are but warriors for the working-day;

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Our gayness and our gilt are all besmirch'd

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: With rainy marching in the painful field;

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: There's not a piece of feather in our host--

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Good argument, I hope, we will not fly--

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: And time hath worn us into slovenry:

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: But, by the mass, our hearts are in the trim;

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: And my poor soldiers tell me, yet ere night

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: They'll be in fresher robes, or they will pluck

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: The gay new coats o'er the French soldiers' heads

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: And turn them out of service. If they do this,--

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: As, if God please, they shall,--my ransom then

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Will soon be levied. Herald, save thou thy labour;

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Come thou no more for ransom, gentle herald:

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: They shall have none, I swear, but these my joints;

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Which if they have as I will leave 'em them,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Shall yield them little, tell the constable.

speaker: MONTJOY
text_entry: I shall, King Harry. And so fare thee well:

speaker: MONTJOY
text_entry: Thou never shalt hear herald any more.

speaker: MONTJOY
text_entry: Exit

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: I fear thou'lt once more come again for ransom.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Enter YORK

speaker: YORK
text_entry: My lord, most humbly on my knee I beg

speaker: YORK
text_entry: The leading of the vaward.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Take it, brave York. Now, soldiers, march away:

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: And how thou pleasest, God, dispose the day!

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: SCENE IV. The field of battle.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Alarum. Excursions. Enter PISTOL, French Soldier, and Boy

speaker: PISTOL
text_entry: Yield, cur!

speaker: French Soldier
text_entry: Je pense que vous etes gentilhomme de bonne qualite.

speaker: PISTOL
text_entry: Qualtitie calmie custure me! Art thou a gentleman?

speaker: PISTOL
text_entry: what is thy name? discuss.

speaker: French Soldier
text_entry: O Seigneur Dieu!

speaker: PISTOL
text_entry: O, Signieur Dew should be a gentleman:

speaker: PISTOL
text_entry: Perpend my words, O Signieur Dew, and mark;

speaker: PISTOL
text_entry: O Signieur Dew, thou diest on point of fox,

speaker: PISTOL
text_entry: Except, O signieur, thou do give to me

speaker: PISTOL
text_entry: Egregious ransom.

speaker: French Soldier
text_entry: O, prenez misericorde! ayez pitie de moi!

speaker: PISTOL
text_entry: Moy shall not serve; I will have forty moys;

speaker: PISTOL
text_entry: Or I will fetch thy rim out at thy throat

speaker: PISTOL
text_entry: In drops of crimson blood.

speaker: French Soldier
text_entry: Est-il impossible d'echapper la force de ton bras?

speaker: PISTOL
text_entry: Brass, cur!

speaker: PISTOL
text_entry: Thou damned and luxurious mountain goat,

speaker: PISTOL
text_entry: Offer'st me brass?

speaker: French Soldier
text_entry: O pardonnez moi!

speaker: PISTOL
text_entry: Say'st thou me so? is that a ton of moys?

speaker: PISTOL
text_entry: Come hither, boy: ask me this slave in French

speaker: PISTOL
text_entry: What is his name.

speaker: Boy
text_entry: Ecoutez: comment etes-vous appele?

speaker: French Soldier
text_entry: Monsieur le Fer.

speaker: Boy
text_entry: He says his name is Master Fer.

speaker: PISTOL
text_entry: Master Fer! I'll fer him, and firk him, and ferret

speaker: PISTOL
text_entry: him: discuss the same in French unto him.

speaker: Boy
text_entry: I do not know the French for fer, and ferret, and firk.

speaker: PISTOL
text_entry: Bid him prepare; for I will cut his throat.

speaker: French Soldier
text_entry: Que dit-il, monsieur?

speaker: Boy
text_entry: Il me commande de vous dire que vous faites vous

speaker: Boy
text_entry: pret; car ce soldat ici est dispose tout a cette

speaker: Boy
text_entry: heure de couper votre gorge.

speaker: PISTOL
text_entry: Owy, cuppele gorge, permafoy,

speaker: PISTOL
text_entry: Peasant, unless thou give me crowns, brave crowns;

speaker: PISTOL
text_entry: Or mangled shalt thou be by this my sword.

speaker: French Soldier
text_entry: O, je vous supplie, pour l'amour de Dieu, me

speaker: French Soldier
text_entry: pardonner! Je suis gentilhomme de bonne maison:

speaker: French Soldier
text_entry: gardez ma vie, et je vous donnerai deux cents ecus.

speaker: PISTOL
text_entry: What are his words?

speaker: Boy
text_entry: He prays you to save his life: he is a gentleman of

speaker: Boy
text_entry: a good house; and for his ransom he will give you

speaker: Boy
text_entry: two hundred crowns.

speaker: PISTOL
text_entry: Tell him my fury shall abate, and I the crowns will take.

speaker: French Soldier
text_entry: Petit monsieur, que dit-il?

speaker: Boy
text_entry: Encore qu'il est contre son jurement de pardonner

speaker: Boy
text_entry: aucun prisonnier, neanmoins, pour les ecus que vous

speaker: Boy
text_entry: l'avez promis, il est content de vous donner la

speaker: Boy
text_entry: liberte, le franchisement.

speaker: French Soldier
text_entry: Sur mes genoux je vous donne mille remercimens; et

speaker: French Soldier
text_entry: je m'estime heureux que je suis tombe entre les

speaker: French Soldier
text_entry: mains d'un chevalier, je pense, le plus brave,

speaker: French Soldier
text_entry: vaillant, et tres distingue seigneur d'Angleterre.

speaker: PISTOL
text_entry: Expound unto me, boy.

speaker: Boy
text_entry: He gives you, upon his knees, a thousand thanks; and

speaker: Boy
text_entry: he esteems himself happy that he hath fallen into

speaker: Boy
text_entry: the hands of one, as he thinks, the most brave,

speaker: Boy
text_entry: valorous, and thrice-worthy signieur of England.

speaker: PISTOL
text_entry: As I suck blood, I will some mercy show.

speaker: PISTOL
text_entry: Follow me!

speaker: Boy
text_entry: Suivez-vous le grand capitaine.

speaker: Boy
text_entry: Exeunt PISTOL, and French Soldier

speaker: Boy
text_entry: I did never know so full a voice issue from so

speaker: Boy
text_entry: empty a heart: but the saying is true 'The empty

speaker: Boy
text_entry: vessel makes the greatest sound.' Bardolph and Nym

speaker: Boy
text_entry: had ten times more valour than this roaring devil i'

speaker: Boy
text_entry: the old play, that every one may pare his nails with

speaker: Boy
text_entry: a wooden dagger; and they are both hanged; and so

speaker: Boy
text_entry: would this be, if he durst steal any thing

speaker: Boy
text_entry: adventurously. I must stay with the lackeys, with

speaker: Boy
text_entry: the luggage of our camp: the French might have a

speaker: Boy
text_entry: good prey of us, if he knew of it; for there is

speaker: Boy
text_entry: none to guard it but boys.

speaker: Boy
text_entry: Exit

speaker: Boy
text_entry: SCENE V. Another part of the field.

speaker: Boy
text_entry: Enter Constable, ORLEANS, BOURBON, DAUPHIN, and RAMBURES

speaker: Constable
text_entry: O diable!

speaker: ORLEANS
text_entry: O seigneur! le jour est perdu, tout est perdu!

speaker: DAUPHIN
text_entry: Mort de ma vie! all is confounded, all!

speaker: DAUPHIN
text_entry: Reproach and everlasting shame

speaker: DAUPHIN
text_entry: Sits mocking in our plumes. O merchante fortune!

speaker: DAUPHIN
text_entry: Do not run away.

speaker: DAUPHIN
text_entry: A short alarum

speaker: Constable
text_entry: Why, all our ranks are broke.

speaker: DAUPHIN
text_entry: O perdurable shame! let's stab ourselves.

speaker: DAUPHIN
text_entry: Be these the wretches that we play'd at dice for?

speaker: ORLEANS
text_entry: Is this the king we sent to for his ransom?

speaker: BOURBON
text_entry: Shame and eternal shame, nothing but shame!

speaker: BOURBON
text_entry: Let us die in honour: once more back again;

speaker: BOURBON
text_entry: And he that will not follow Bourbon now,

speaker: BOURBON
text_entry: Let him go hence, and with his cap in hand,

speaker: BOURBON
text_entry: Like a base pander, hold the chamber-door

speaker: BOURBON
text_entry: Whilst by a slave, no gentler than my dog,

speaker: BOURBON
text_entry: His fairest daughter is contaminated.

speaker: Constable
text_entry: Disorder, that hath spoil'd us, friend us now!

speaker: Constable
text_entry: Let us on heaps go offer up our lives.

speaker: ORLEANS
text_entry: We are enow yet living in the field

speaker: ORLEANS
text_entry: To smother up the English in our throngs,

speaker: ORLEANS
text_entry: If any order might be thought upon.

speaker: BOURBON
text_entry: The devil take order now! I'll to the throng:

speaker: BOURBON
text_entry: Let life be short; else shame will be too long.

speaker: BOURBON
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: BOURBON
text_entry: SCENE VI. Another part of the field.

speaker: BOURBON
text_entry: Alarums. Enter KING HENRY and forces, EXETER, and others

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Well have we done, thrice valiant countrymen:

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: But all's not done; yet keep the French the field.

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: The Duke of York commends him to your majesty.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Lives he, good uncle? thrice within this hour

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: I saw him down; thrice up again and fighting;

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: From helmet to the spur all blood he was.

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: In which array, brave soldier, doth he lie,

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: Larding the plain; and by his bloody side,

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: Yoke-fellow to his honour-owing wounds,

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: The noble Earl of Suffolk also lies.

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: Suffolk first died: and York, all haggled over,

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: Comes to him, where in gore he lay insteep'd,

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: And takes him by the beard; kisses the gashes

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: That bloodily did spawn upon his face;

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: And cries aloud 'Tarry, dear cousin Suffolk!

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: My soul shall thine keep company to heaven;

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: Tarry, sweet soul, for mine, then fly abreast,

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: As in this glorious and well-foughten field

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: We kept together in our chivalry!'

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: Upon these words I came and cheer'd him up:

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: He smiled me in the face, raught me his hand,

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: And, with a feeble gripe, says 'Dear my lord,

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: Commend my service to me sovereign.'

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: So did he turn and over Suffolk's neck

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: He threw his wounded arm and kiss'd his lips;

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: And so espoused to death, with blood he seal'd

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: A testament of noble-ending love.

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: The pretty and sweet manner of it forced

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: Those waters from me which I would have stopp'd;

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: But I had not so much of man in me,

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: And all my mother came into mine eyes

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: And gave me up to tears.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: I blame you not;

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: For, hearing this, I must perforce compound

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: With mistful eyes, or they will issue too.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Alarum

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: But, hark! what new alarum is this same?

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: The French have reinforced their scatter'd men:

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Then every soldier kill his prisoners:

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Give the word through.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: SCENE VII. Another part of the field.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Enter FLUELLEN and GOWER

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: Kill the poys and the luggage! 'tis expressly

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: against the law of arms: 'tis as arrant a piece of

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: knavery, mark you now, as can be offer't; in your

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: conscience, now, is it not?

speaker: GOWER
text_entry: 'Tis certain there's not a boy left alive; and the

speaker: GOWER
text_entry: cowardly rascals that ran from the battle ha' done

speaker: GOWER
text_entry: this slaughter: besides, they have burned and

speaker: GOWER
text_entry: carried away all that was in the king's tent;

speaker: GOWER
text_entry: wherefore the king, most worthily, hath caused every

speaker: GOWER
text_entry: soldier to cut his prisoner's throat. O, 'tis a

speaker: GOWER
text_entry: gallant king!

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: Ay, he was porn at Monmouth, Captain Gower. What

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: call you the town's name where Alexander the Pig was born!

speaker: GOWER
text_entry: Alexander the Great.

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: Why, I pray you, is not pig great? the pig, or the

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: great, or the mighty, or the huge, or the

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: magnanimous, are all one reckonings, save the phrase

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: is a little variations.

speaker: GOWER
text_entry: I think Alexander the Great was born in Macedon; his

speaker: GOWER
text_entry: father was called Philip of Macedon, as I take it.

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: I think it is in Macedon where Alexander is porn. I

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: tell you, captain, if you look in the maps of the

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: 'orld, I warrant you sall find, in the comparisons

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: between Macedon and Monmouth, that the situations,

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: look you, is both alike. There is a river in

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: Macedon; and there is also moreover a river at

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: Monmouth: it is called Wye at Monmouth; but it is

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: out of my prains what is the name of the other

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: river; but 'tis all one, 'tis alike as my fingers is

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: to my fingers, and there is salmons in both. If you

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: mark Alexander's life well, Harry of Monmouth's life

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: is come after it indifferent well; for there is

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: figures in all things. Alexander, God knows, and

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: you know, in his rages, and his furies, and his

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: wraths, and his cholers, and his moods, and his

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: displeasures, and his indignations, and also being a

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: little intoxicates in his prains, did, in his ales and

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: his angers, look you, kill his best friend, Cleitus.

speaker: GOWER
text_entry: Our king is not like him in that: he never killed

speaker: GOWER
text_entry: any of his friends.

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: It is not well done, mark you now take the tales out

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: of my mouth, ere it is made and finished. I speak

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: but in the figures and comparisons of it: as

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: Alexander killed his friend Cleitus, being in his

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: ales and his cups; so also Harry Monmouth, being in

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: his right wits and his good judgments, turned away

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: the fat knight with the great belly-doublet: he

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: was full of jests, and gipes, and knaveries, and

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: mocks; I have forgot his name.

speaker: GOWER
text_entry: Sir John Falstaff.

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: That is he: I'll tell you there is good men porn at Monmouth.

speaker: GOWER
text_entry: Here comes his majesty.

speaker: GOWER
text_entry: Alarum. Enter KING HENRY, and forces; WARWICK, GLOUCESTER, EXETER, and others

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: I was not angry since I came to France

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Until this instant. Take a trumpet, herald;

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Ride thou unto the horsemen on yon hill:

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: If they will fight with us, bid them come down,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Or void the field; they do offend our sight:

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: If they'll do neither, we will come to them,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: And make them skirr away, as swift as stones

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Enforced from the old Assyrian slings:

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Besides, we'll cut the throats of those we have,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: And not a man of them that we shall take

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Shall taste our mercy. Go and tell them so.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Enter MONTJOY

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: Here comes the herald of the French, my liege.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: His eyes are humbler than they used to be.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: How now! what means this, herald? know'st thou not

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: That I have  fined these bones of mine for ransom?

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Comest thou again for ransom?

speaker: MONTJOY
text_entry: No, great king:

speaker: MONTJOY
text_entry: I come to thee for charitable licence,

speaker: MONTJOY
text_entry: That we may wander o'er this bloody field

speaker: MONTJOY
text_entry: To look our dead, and then to bury them;

speaker: MONTJOY
text_entry: To sort our nobles from our common men.

speaker: MONTJOY
text_entry: For many of our princes--woe the while!--

speaker: MONTJOY
text_entry: Lie drown'd and soak'd in mercenary blood;

speaker: MONTJOY
text_entry: So do our vulgar drench their peasant limbs

speaker: MONTJOY
text_entry: In blood of princes; and their wounded steeds

speaker: MONTJOY
text_entry: Fret fetlock deep in gore and with wild rage

speaker: MONTJOY
text_entry: Yerk out their armed heels at their dead masters,

speaker: MONTJOY
text_entry: Killing them twice. O, give us leave, great king,

speaker: MONTJOY
text_entry: To view the field in safety and dispose

speaker: MONTJOY
text_entry: Of their dead bodies!

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: I tell thee truly, herald,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: I know not if the day be ours or no;

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: For yet a many of your horsemen peer

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: And gallop o'er the field.

speaker: MONTJOY
text_entry: The day is yours.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Praised be God, and not our strength, for it!

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: What is this castle call'd that stands hard by?

speaker: MONTJOY
text_entry: They call it Agincourt.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Then call we this the field of Agincourt,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Fought on the day of Crispin Crispianus.

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: Your grandfather of famous memory, an't please your

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: majesty, and your great-uncle Edward the Plack

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: Prince of Wales, as I have read in the chronicles,

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: fought a most prave pattle here in France.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: They did, Fluellen.

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: Your majesty says very true: if your majesties is

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: remembered of it, the Welshmen did good service in a

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: garden where leeks did grow, wearing leeks in their

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: Monmouth caps; which, your majesty know, to this

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: hour is an honourable badge of the service; and I do

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: believe your majesty takes no scorn to wear the leek

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: upon Saint Tavy's day.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: I wear it for a memorable honour;

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: For I am Welsh, you know, good countryman.

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: All the water in Wye cannot wash your majesty's

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: Welsh plood out of your pody, I can tell you that:

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: God pless it and preserve it, as long as it pleases

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: his grace, and his majesty too!

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Thanks, good my countryman.

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: By Jeshu, I am your majesty's countryman, I care not

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: who know it; I will confess it to all the 'orld: I

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: need not to be ashamed of your majesty, praised be

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: God, so long as your majesty is an honest man.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: God keep me so! Our heralds go with him:

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Bring me just notice of the numbers dead

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: On both our parts. Call yonder fellow hither.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Points to WILLIAMS. Exeunt Heralds with Montjoy

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: Soldier, you must come to the king.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Soldier, why wearest thou that glove in thy cap?

speaker: WILLIAMS
text_entry: An't please your majesty, 'tis the gage of one that

speaker: WILLIAMS
text_entry: I should fight withal, if he be alive.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: An Englishman?

speaker: WILLIAMS
text_entry: An't please your majesty, a rascal that swaggered

speaker: WILLIAMS
text_entry: with me last night; who, if alive and ever dare to

speaker: WILLIAMS
text_entry: challenge this glove, I have sworn to take him a box

speaker: WILLIAMS
text_entry: o' th' ear: or if I can see my glove in his cap,

speaker: WILLIAMS
text_entry: which he swore, as he was a soldier, he would wear

speaker: WILLIAMS
text_entry: if alive, I will strike it out soundly.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: What think you, Captain Fluellen? is it fit this

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: soldier keep his oath?

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: He is a craven and a villain else, an't please your

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: majesty, in my conscience.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: It may be his enemy is a gentleman of great sort,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: quite from the answer of his degree.

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: Though he be as good a gentleman as the devil is, as

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: Lucifer and Belzebub himself, it is necessary, look

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: your grace, that he keep his vow and his oath: if

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: he be perjured, see you now, his reputation is as

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: arrant a villain and a Jacksauce, as ever his black

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: shoe trod upon God's ground and his earth, in my

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: conscience, la!

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Then keep thy vow, sirrah, when thou meetest the fellow.

speaker: WILLIAMS
text_entry: So I will, my liege, as I live.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Who servest thou under?

speaker: WILLIAMS
text_entry: Under Captain Gower, my liege.

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: Gower is a good captain, and is good knowledge and

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: literatured in the wars.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Call him hither to me, soldier.

speaker: WILLIAMS
text_entry: I will, my liege.

speaker: WILLIAMS
text_entry: Exit

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Here, Fluellen; wear thou this favour for me and

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: stick it in thy cap: when Alencon and myself were

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: down together, I plucked this glove from his helm:

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: if any man challenge this, he is a friend to

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Alencon, and an enemy to our person; if thou

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: encounter any such, apprehend him, an thou dost me love.

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: Your grace doo's me as great honours as can be

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: desired in the hearts of his subjects: I would fain

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: see the man, that has but two legs, that shall find

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: himself aggrieved at this glove; that is all; but I

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: would fain see it once, an please God of his grace

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: that I might see.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Knowest thou Gower?

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: He is my dear friend, an please you.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Pray thee, go seek him, and bring him to my tent.

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: I will fetch him.

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: Exit

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: My Lord of Warwick, and my brother Gloucester,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Follow Fluellen closely at the heels:

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: The glove which I have given him for a favour

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: May haply purchase him a box o' th' ear;

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: It is the soldier's; I by bargain should

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Wear it myself. Follow, good cousin Warwick:

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: If that the soldier strike him, as I judge

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: By his blunt bearing he will keep his word,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Some sudden mischief may arise of it;

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: For I do know Fluellen valiant

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: And, touched with choler, hot as gunpowder,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: And quickly will return an injury:

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Follow and see there be no harm between them.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Go you with me, uncle of Exeter.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: SCENE VIII. Before KING HENRY'S pavilion.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Enter GOWER and WILLIAMS

speaker: WILLIAMS
text_entry: I warrant it is to knight you, captain.

speaker: WILLIAMS
text_entry: Enter FLUELLEN

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: God's will and his pleasure, captain, I beseech you

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: now, come apace to the king: there is more good

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: toward you peradventure than is in your knowledge to dream of.

speaker: WILLIAMS
text_entry: Sir, know you this glove?

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: Know the glove! I know the glove is glove.

speaker: WILLIAMS
text_entry: I know this; and thus I challenge it.

speaker: WILLIAMS
text_entry: Strikes him

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: 'Sblood! an arrant traitor as any is in the

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: universal world, or in France, or in England!

speaker: GOWER
text_entry: How now, sir! you villain!

speaker: WILLIAMS
text_entry: Do you think I'll be forsworn?

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: Stand away, Captain Gower; I will give treason his

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: payment into ploughs, I warrant you.

speaker: WILLIAMS
text_entry: I am no traitor.

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: That's a lie in thy throat. I charge you in his

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: majesty's name, apprehend him: he's a friend of the

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: Duke Alencon's.

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: Enter WARWICK and GLOUCESTER

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: How now, how now! what's the matter?

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: My Lord of Warwick, here is--praised be God for it!

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: --a most contagious treason come to light, look

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: you, as you shall desire in a summer's day. Here is

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: his majesty.

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: Enter KING HENRY and EXETER

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: How now! what's the matter?

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: My liege, here is a villain and a traitor, that,

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: look your grace, has struck the glove which your

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: majesty is take out of the helmet of Alencon.

speaker: WILLIAMS
text_entry: My liege, this was my glove; here is the fellow of

speaker: WILLIAMS
text_entry: it; and he that I gave it to in change promised to

speaker: WILLIAMS
text_entry: wear it in his cap: I promised to strike him, if he

speaker: WILLIAMS
text_entry: did: I met this man with my glove in his cap, and I

speaker: WILLIAMS
text_entry: have been as good as my word.

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: Your majesty hear now, saving your majesty's

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: manhood, what an arrant, rascally, beggarly, lousy

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: knave it is: I hope your majesty is pear me

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: testimony and witness, and will avouchment, that

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: this is the glove of Alencon, that your majesty is

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: give me; in your conscience, now?

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Give me thy glove, soldier: look, here is the

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: fellow of it.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: 'Twas I, indeed, thou promised'st to strike;

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: And thou hast given me most bitter terms.

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: An please your majesty, let his neck answer for it,

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: if there is any martial law in the world.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: How canst thou make me satisfaction?

speaker: WILLIAMS
text_entry: All offences, my lord, come from the heart: never

speaker: WILLIAMS
text_entry: came any from mine that might offend your majesty.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: It was ourself thou didst abuse.

speaker: WILLIAMS
text_entry: Your majesty came not like yourself: you appeared to

speaker: WILLIAMS
text_entry: me but as a common man; witness the night, your

speaker: WILLIAMS
text_entry: garments, your lowliness; and what your highness

speaker: WILLIAMS
text_entry: suffered under that shape, I beseech you take it for

speaker: WILLIAMS
text_entry: your own fault and not mine: for had you been as I

speaker: WILLIAMS
text_entry: took you for, I made no offence; therefore, I

speaker: WILLIAMS
text_entry: beseech your highness, pardon me.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Here, uncle Exeter, fill this glove with crowns,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: And give it to this fellow. Keep it, fellow;

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: And wear it for an honour in thy cap

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Till I do challenge it. Give him the crowns:

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: And, captain, you must needs be friends with him.

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: By this day and this light, the fellow has mettle

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: enough in his belly. Hold, there is twelve pence

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: for you; and I pray you to serve Got, and keep you

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: out of prawls, and prabbles' and quarrels, and

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: dissensions, and, I warrant you, it is the better for you.

speaker: WILLIAMS
text_entry: I will none of your money.

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: It is with a good will; I can tell you, it will

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: serve you to mend your shoes: come, wherefore should

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: you be so pashful? your shoes is not so good: 'tis

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: a good silling, I warrant you, or I will change it.

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: Enter an English Herald

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Now, herald, are the dead number'd?

speaker: Herald
text_entry: Here is the number of the slaughter'd French.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: What prisoners of good sort are taken, uncle?

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: Charles Duke of Orleans, nephew to the king;

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: John Duke of Bourbon, and Lord Bouciqualt:

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: Of other lords and barons, knights and squires,

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: Full fifteen hundred, besides common men.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: This note doth tell me of ten thousand French

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: That in the field lie slain: of princes, in this number,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: And nobles bearing banners, there lie dead

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: One hundred twenty six: added to these,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Of knights, esquires, and gallant gentlemen,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Eight thousand and four hundred; of the which,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Five hundred were but yesterday dubb'd knights:

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: So that, in these ten thousand they have lost,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: There are but sixteen hundred mercenaries;

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: The rest are princes, barons, lords, knights, squires,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: And gentlemen of blood and quality.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: The names of those their nobles that lie dead:

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Charles Delabreth, high constable of France;

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Jaques of Chatillon, admiral of France;

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: The master of the cross-bows, Lord Rambures;

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Great Master of France, the brave Sir Guichard Dolphin,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: John Duke of Alencon, Anthony Duke of Brabant,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: The brother of the Duke of Burgundy,

speaker: KING HENRY V
