text_entry: And Edward Duke of Bar: of lusty earls,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Grandpre and Roussi, Fauconberg and Foix,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Beaumont and Marle, Vaudemont and Lestrale.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Here was a royal fellowship of death!

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Where is the number of our English dead?

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Herald shews him another paper

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Edward the Duke of York, the Earl of Suffolk,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Sir Richard Ketly, Davy Gam, esquire:

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: None else of name; and of all other men

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: But five and twenty. O God, thy arm was here;

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: And not to us, but to thy arm alone,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Ascribe we all! When, without stratagem,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: But in plain shock and even play of battle,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Was ever known so great and little loss

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: On one part and on the other? Take it, God,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: For it is none but thine!

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: 'Tis wonderful!

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Come, go we in procession to the village.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: And be it death proclaimed through our host

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: To boast of this or take the praise from God

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Which is his only.

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: Is it not lawful, an please your majesty, to tell

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: how many is killed?

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Yes, captain; but with this acknowledgement,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: That God fought for us.

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: Yes, my conscience, he did us great good.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Do we all holy rites;

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Let there be sung 'Non nobis' and 'Te Deum;'

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: The dead with charity enclosed in clay:

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: And then to Calais; and to England then:

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Where ne'er from France arrived more happy men.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: ACT V

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: PROLOGUE

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Enter Chorus

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: Vouchsafe to those that have not read the story,

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: That I may prompt them: and of such as have,

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: I humbly pray them to admit the excuse

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: Of time, of numbers and due course of things,

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: Which cannot in their huge and proper life

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: Be here presented. Now we bear the king

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: Toward Calais: grant him there; there seen,

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: Heave him away upon your winged thoughts

text_entry: Athwart the sea. Behold, the English beach

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: Pales in the flood with men, with wives and boys,

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: Whose shouts and claps out-voice the deep mouth'd sea,

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: Which like a mighty whiffler 'fore the king

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: Seems to prepare his way: so let him land,

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: And solemnly see him set on to London.

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: So swift a pace hath thought that even now

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: You may imagine him upon Blackheath;

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: Where that his lords desire him to have borne

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: His bruised helmet and his bended sword

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: Before him through the city: he forbids it,

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: Being free from vainness and self-glorious pride;

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: Giving full trophy, signal and ostent

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: Quite from himself to God. But now behold,

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: In the quick forge and working-house of thought,

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: How London doth pour out her citizens!

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: The mayor and all his brethren in best sort,

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: Like to the senators of the antique Rome,

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: With the plebeians swarming at their heels,

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: Go forth and fetch their conquering Caesar in:

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: As, by a lower but loving likelihood,

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: Were now the general of our gracious empress,

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: As in good time he may, from Ireland coming,

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: Bringing rebellion broached on his sword,

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: How many would the peaceful city quit,

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: To welcome him! much more, and much more cause,

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: Did they this Harry. Now in London place him;

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: As yet the lamentation of the French

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: Invites the King of England's stay at home;

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: The emperor's coming in behalf of France,

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: To order peace between them; and omit

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: All the occurrences, whatever chanced,

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: Till Harry's back-return again to France:

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: There must we bring him; and myself have play'd

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: The interim, by remembering you 'tis past.

text_entry: Then brook abridgment, and your eyes advance,

speaker: Chorus

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: SCENE I. France. The English camp.

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: Enter FLUELLEN and GOWER

speaker: GOWER
text_entry: Nay, that's right; but why wear you your leek today?

speaker: GOWER
text_entry: Saint Davy's day is past.

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: There is occasions and causes why and wherefore in

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: all things: I will tell you, asse my friend,

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: Captain Gower: the rascally, scald, beggarly,

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: lousy, pragging knave, Pistol, which you and

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: yourself and all the world know to be no petter

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: than a fellow, look you now, of no merits, he is

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: come to me and prings me pread and salt yesterday,

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: look you, and bid me eat my leek: it was in place

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: where I could not breed no contention with him; but

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: I will be so bold as to wear it in my cap till I see

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: him once again, and then I will tell him a little

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: piece of my desires.

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: Enter PISTOL

speaker: GOWER
text_entry: Why, here he comes, swelling like a turkey-cock.

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: 'Tis no matter for his swellings nor his

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: turkey-cocks. God pless you, Aunchient Pistol! you

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: scurvy, lousy knave, God pless you!

speaker: PISTOL
text_entry: Ha! art thou bedlam? dost thou thirst, base Trojan,

speaker: PISTOL
text_entry: To have me fold up Parca's fatal web?

speaker: PISTOL
text_entry: Hence! I am qualmish at the smell of leek.

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: I peseech you heartily, scurvy, lousy knave, at my

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: desires, and my requests, and my petitions, to eat,

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: look you, this leek: because, look you, you do not

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: love it, nor your affections and your appetites and

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: your digestions doo's not agree with it, I would

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: desire you to eat it.

speaker: PISTOL
text_entry: Not for Cadwallader and all his goats.

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: There is one goat for you.

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: Strikes him

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: Will you be so good, scauld knave, as eat it?

speaker: PISTOL
text_entry: Base Trojan, thou shalt die.

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: You say very true, scauld knave, when God's will is:

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: I will desire you to live in the mean time, and eat

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: your victuals: come, there is sauce for it.

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: Strikes him

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: You called me yesterday mountain-squire; but I will

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: make you to-day a squire of low degree. I pray you,

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: fall to: if you can mock a leek, you can eat a leek.

speaker: GOWER
text_entry: Enough, captain: you have astonished him.

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: I say, I will make him eat some part of my leek, or

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: I will peat his pate four days. Bite, I pray you; it

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: is good for your green wound and your ploody coxcomb.

speaker: PISTOL
text_entry: Must I bite?

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: Yes, certainly, and out of doubt and out of question

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: too, and ambiguities.

speaker: PISTOL
text_entry: By this leek, I will most horribly revenge: I eat

speaker: PISTOL
text_entry: and eat, I swear--

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: Eat, I pray you: will you have some more sauce to

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: your leek? there is not enough leek to swear by.

speaker: PISTOL
text_entry: Quiet thy cudgel; thou dost see I eat.

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: Much good do you, scauld knave, heartily. Nay, pray

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: you, throw none away; the skin is good for your

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: broken coxcomb. When you take occasions to see leeks

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: hereafter, I pray you, mock at 'em; that is all.

speaker: PISTOL
text_entry: Good.

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: Ay, leeks is good: hold you, there is a groat to

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: heal your pate.

speaker: PISTOL
text_entry: Me a groat!

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: Yes, verily and in truth, you shall take it; or I

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: have another leek in my pocket, which you shall eat.

speaker: PISTOL
text_entry: I take thy groat in earnest of revenge.

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: If I owe you any thing, I will pay you in cudgels:

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: you shall be a woodmonger, and buy nothing of me but

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: cudgels. God b' wi' you, and keep you, and heal your pate.

speaker: FLUELLEN
text_entry: Exit

speaker: PISTOL
text_entry: All hell shall stir for this.

speaker: GOWER
text_entry: Go, go; you are a counterfeit cowardly knave. Will

speaker: GOWER
text_entry: you mock at an ancient tradition, begun upon an

speaker: GOWER
text_entry: honourable respect, and worn as a memorable trophy of

speaker: GOWER
text_entry: predeceased valour and dare not avouch in your deeds

speaker: GOWER
text_entry: any of your words? I have seen you gleeking and

speaker: GOWER
text_entry: galling at this gentleman twice or thrice. You

speaker: GOWER
text_entry: thought, because he could not speak English in the

speaker: GOWER
text_entry: native garb, he could not therefore handle an

speaker: GOWER
text_entry: English cudgel: you find it otherwise; and

speaker: GOWER
text_entry: henceforth let a Welsh correction teach you a good

speaker: GOWER
text_entry: English condition. Fare ye well.

speaker: GOWER
text_entry: Exit

speaker: PISTOL
text_entry: Doth Fortune play the huswife with me now?

speaker: PISTOL
text_entry: News have I, that my Nell is dead i' the spital

speaker: PISTOL
text_entry: Of malady of France;

speaker: PISTOL
text_entry: And there my rendezvous is quite cut off.

speaker: PISTOL
text_entry: Old I do wax; and from my weary limbs

speaker: PISTOL
text_entry: Honour is cudgelled. Well, bawd I'll turn,

speaker: PISTOL
text_entry: And something lean to cutpurse of quick hand.

speaker: PISTOL
text_entry: To England will I steal, and there I'll steal:

speaker: PISTOL
text_entry: And patches will I get unto these cudgell'd scars,

speaker: PISTOL
text_entry: And swear I got them in the Gallia wars.

speaker: PISTOL
text_entry: Exit

speaker: PISTOL
text_entry: SCENE II. France. A royal palace.

speaker: PISTOL
text_entry: Enter, at one door KING HENRY, EXETER, BEDFORD,  GLOUCESTER, WARWICK, WESTMORELAND, and other Lords;  at another, the FRENCH KING, QUEEN ISABEL, the  PRINCESS KATHARINE, ALICE and other Ladies; the DUKE of BURGUNDY, and his train

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Peace to this meeting, wherefore we are met!

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Unto our brother France, and to our sister,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Health and fair time of day; joy and good wishes

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: To our most fair and princely cousin Katharine;

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: And, as a branch and member of this royalty,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: By whom this great assembly is contrived,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: We do salute you, Duke of Burgundy;

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: And, princes French, and peers, health to you all!

speaker: KING OF FRANCE
text_entry: Right joyous are we to behold your face,

speaker: KING OF FRANCE
text_entry: Most worthy brother England; fairly met:

speaker: KING OF FRANCE
text_entry: So are you, princes English, every one.

speaker: QUEEN ISABEL
text_entry: So happy be the issue, brother England,

speaker: QUEEN ISABEL
text_entry: Of this good day and of this gracious meeting,

speaker: QUEEN ISABEL
text_entry: As we are now glad to behold your eyes;

speaker: QUEEN ISABEL
text_entry: Your eyes, which hitherto have borne in them

speaker: QUEEN ISABEL
text_entry: Against the French, that met them in their bent,

speaker: QUEEN ISABEL
text_entry: The fatal balls of murdering basilisks:

speaker: QUEEN ISABEL
text_entry: The venom of such looks, we fairly hope,

speaker: QUEEN ISABEL
text_entry: Have lost their quality, and that this day

speaker: QUEEN ISABEL
text_entry: Shall change all griefs and quarrels into love.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: To cry amen to that, thus we appear.

speaker: QUEEN ISABEL
text_entry: You English princes all, I do salute you.

speaker: BURGUNDY
text_entry: My duty to you both, on equal love,

speaker: BURGUNDY
text_entry: Great Kings of France and England! That I have labour'd,

speaker: BURGUNDY
text_entry: With all my wits, my pains and strong endeavours,

speaker: BURGUNDY
text_entry: To bring your most imperial majesties

speaker: BURGUNDY
text_entry: Unto this bar and royal interview,

speaker: BURGUNDY
text_entry: Your mightiness on both parts best can witness.

speaker: BURGUNDY
text_entry: Since then my office hath so far prevail'd

speaker: BURGUNDY
text_entry: That, face to face and royal eye to eye,

speaker: BURGUNDY
text_entry: You have congreeted, let it not disgrace me,

speaker: BURGUNDY
text_entry: If I demand, before this royal view,

speaker: BURGUNDY
text_entry: What rub or what impediment there is,

speaker: BURGUNDY
text_entry: Why that the naked, poor and mangled Peace,

speaker: BURGUNDY
text_entry: Dear nurse of arts and joyful births,

speaker: BURGUNDY
text_entry: Should not in this best garden of the world

speaker: BURGUNDY
text_entry: Our fertile France, put up her lovely visage?

speaker: BURGUNDY
text_entry: Alas, she hath from France too long been chased,

speaker: BURGUNDY
text_entry: And all her husbandry doth lie on heaps,

speaker: BURGUNDY
text_entry: Corrupting in its own fertility.

speaker: BURGUNDY
text_entry: Her vine, the merry cheerer of the heart,

speaker: BURGUNDY
text_entry: Unpruned dies; her hedges even-pleach'd,

speaker: BURGUNDY
text_entry: Like prisoners wildly overgrown with hair,

speaker: BURGUNDY
text_entry: Put forth disorder'd twigs; her fallow leas

speaker: BURGUNDY
text_entry: The darnel, hemlock and rank fumitory

speaker: BURGUNDY
text_entry: Doth root upon, while that the coulter rusts

speaker: BURGUNDY
text_entry: That should deracinate such savagery;

speaker: BURGUNDY
text_entry: The even mead, that erst brought sweetly forth

speaker: BURGUNDY
text_entry: The freckled cowslip, burnet and green clover,

speaker: BURGUNDY
text_entry: Wanting the scythe, all uncorrected, rank,

speaker: BURGUNDY
text_entry: Conceives by idleness and nothing teems

speaker: BURGUNDY
text_entry: But hateful docks, rough thistles, kecksies, burs,

speaker: BURGUNDY
text_entry: Losing both beauty and utility.

speaker: BURGUNDY
text_entry: And as our vineyards, fallows, meads and hedges,

speaker: BURGUNDY
text_entry: Defective in their natures, grow to wildness,

speaker: BURGUNDY
text_entry: Even so our houses and ourselves and children

speaker: BURGUNDY
text_entry: Have lost, or do not learn for want of time,

speaker: BURGUNDY
text_entry: The sciences that should become our country;

speaker: BURGUNDY
text_entry: But grow like savages,--as soldiers will

speaker: BURGUNDY
text_entry: That nothing do but meditate on blood,--

speaker: BURGUNDY
text_entry: To swearing and stern looks, diffused attire

speaker: BURGUNDY
text_entry: And every thing that seems unnatural.

speaker: BURGUNDY
text_entry: Which to reduce into our former favour

speaker: BURGUNDY
text_entry: You are assembled: and my speech entreats

speaker: BURGUNDY
text_entry: That I may know the let, why gentle Peace

speaker: BURGUNDY
text_entry: Should not expel these inconveniences

speaker: BURGUNDY
text_entry: And bless us with her former qualities.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: If, Duke of Burgundy, you would the peace,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Whose want gives growth to the imperfections

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Which you have cited, you must buy that peace

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: With full accord to all our just demands;

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Whose tenors and particular effects

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: You have enscheduled briefly in your hands.

speaker: BURGUNDY
text_entry: The king hath heard them; to the which as yet

speaker: BURGUNDY
text_entry: There is no answer made.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Well then the peace,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Which you before so urged, lies in his answer.

speaker: KING OF FRANCE
text_entry: I have but with a cursorary eye

speaker: KING OF FRANCE
text_entry: O'erglanced the articles: pleaseth your grace

speaker: KING OF FRANCE
text_entry: To appoint some of your council presently

speaker: KING OF FRANCE
text_entry: To sit with us once more, with better heed

speaker: KING OF FRANCE
text_entry: To re-survey them, we will suddenly

speaker: KING OF FRANCE
text_entry: Pass our accept and peremptory answer.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Brother, we shall. Go, uncle Exeter,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: And brother Clarence, and you, brother Gloucester,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Warwick and Huntingdon, go with the king;

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: And take with you free power to ratify,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Augment, or alter, as your wisdoms best

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Shall see advantageable for our dignity,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Any thing in or out of our demands,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: And we'll consign thereto. Will you, fair sister,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Go with the princes, or stay here with us?

speaker: QUEEN ISABEL
text_entry: Our gracious brother, I will go with them:

speaker: QUEEN ISABEL
text_entry: Haply a woman's voice may do some good,

speaker: QUEEN ISABEL
text_entry: When articles too nicely urged be stood on.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Yet leave our cousin Katharine here with us:

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: She is our capital demand, comprised

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Within the fore-rank of our articles.

speaker: QUEEN ISABEL
text_entry: She hath good leave.

speaker: QUEEN ISABEL
text_entry: Exeunt all except HENRY, KATHARINE, and ALICE

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Fair Katharine, and most fair,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Will you vouchsafe to teach a soldier terms

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Such as will enter at a lady's ear

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: And plead his love-suit to her gentle heart?

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: Your majesty shall mock at me; I cannot speak your England.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: O fair Katharine, if you will love me soundly with

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: your French heart, I will be glad to hear you

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: confess it brokenly with your English tongue. Do

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: you like me, Kate?

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: Pardonnez-moi, I cannot tell vat is 'like me.'

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: An angel is like you, Kate, and you are like an angel.

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: Que dit-il? que je suis semblable a les anges?

speaker: ALICE
text_entry: Oui, vraiment, sauf votre grace, ainsi dit-il.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: I said so, dear Katharine; and I must not blush to

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: affirm it.

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: O bon Dieu! les langues des hommes sont pleines de

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: tromperies.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: What says she, fair one? that the tongues of men

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: are full of deceits?

speaker: ALICE
text_entry: Oui, dat de tongues of de mans is be full of

speaker: ALICE
text_entry: deceits: dat is de princess.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: The princess is the better Englishwoman. I' faith,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Kate, my wooing is fit for thy understanding: I am

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: glad thou canst speak no better English; for, if

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: thou couldst, thou wouldst find me such a plain king

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: that thou wouldst think I had sold my farm to buy my

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: crown. I know no ways to mince it in love, but

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: directly to say 'I love you:' then if you urge me

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: farther than to say 'do you in faith?' I wear out

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: my suit. Give me your answer; i' faith, do: and so

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: clap hands and a bargain: how say you, lady?

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: Sauf votre honneur, me understand vell.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Marry, if you would put me to verses or to dance for

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: your sake, Kate, why you undid me: for the one, I

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: have neither words nor measure, and for the other, I

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: have no strength in measure, yet a reasonable

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: measure in strength. If I could win a lady at

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: leap-frog, or by vaulting into my saddle with my

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: armour on my back, under the correction of bragging

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: be it spoken. I should quickly leap into a wife.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Or if I might buffet for my love, or bound my horse

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: for her favours, I could lay on like a butcher and

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: sit like a jack-an-apes, never off. But, before God,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Kate, I cannot look greenly nor gasp out my

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: eloquence, nor I have no cunning in protestation;

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: only downright oaths, which I never use till urged,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: nor never break for urging. If thou canst love a

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: fellow of this temper, Kate, whose face is not worth

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: sun-burning, that never looks in his glass for love

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: of any thing he sees there, let thine eye be thy

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: cook. I speak to thee plain soldier: If thou canst

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: love me for this, take me: if not, to say to thee

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: that I shall die, is true; but for thy love, by the

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Lord, no; yet I love thee too. And while thou

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: livest, dear Kate, take a fellow of plain and

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: uncoined constancy; for he perforce must do thee

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: right, because he hath not the gift to woo in other

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: places: for these fellows of infinite tongue, that

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: can rhyme themselves into ladies' favours, they do

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: always reason themselves out again. What! a

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: speaker is but a prater; a rhyme is but a ballad. A

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: good leg will fall; a straight back will stoop; a

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: black beard will turn white; a curled pate will grow

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: bald; a fair face will wither; a full eye will wax

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: hollow: but a good heart, Kate, is the sun and the

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: moon; or, rather, the sun, and not the moon; for it

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: shines bright and never changes, but keeps his

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: course truly. If thou would have such a one, take

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: me; and take me, take a soldier; take a soldier,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: take a king. And what sayest thou then to my love?

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: speak, my fair, and fairly, I pray thee.

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: Is it possible dat I sould love de enemy of France?

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: No; it is not possible you should love the enemy of

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: France, Kate: but, in loving me, you should love

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: the friend of France; for I love France so well that

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: I will not part with a village of it; I will have it

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: all mine: and, Kate, when France is mine and I am

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: yours, then yours is France and you are mine.

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: I cannot tell vat is dat.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: No, Kate? I will tell thee in French; which I am

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: sure will hang upon my tongue like a new-married

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: wife about her husband's neck, hardly to be shook

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: off. Je quand sur le possession de France, et quand

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: vous avez le possession de moi,--let me see, what

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: then? Saint Denis be my speed!--donc votre est

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: France et vous etes mienne. It is as easy for me,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Kate, to conquer the kingdom as to speak so much

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: more French: I shall never move thee in French,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: unless it be to laugh at me.

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: Sauf votre honneur, le Francois que vous parlez, il

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: est meilleur que l'Anglois lequel je parle.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: No, faith, is't not, Kate: but thy speaking of my

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: tongue, and I thine, most truly-falsely, must needs

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: be granted to be much at one. But, Kate, dost thou

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: understand thus much English, canst thou love me?

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: I cannot tell.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Can any of your neighbours tell, Kate? I'll ask

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: them. Come, I know thou lovest me: and at night,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: when you come into your closet, you'll question this

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: gentlewoman about me; and I know, Kate, you will to

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: her dispraise those parts in me that you love with

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: your heart: but, good Kate, mock me mercifully; the

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: rather, gentle princess, because I love thee

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: cruelly. If ever thou beest mine, Kate, as I have a

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: saving faith within me tells me thou shalt, I get

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: thee with scambling, and thou must therefore needs

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: prove a good soldier-breeder: shall not thou and I,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: between Saint Denis and Saint George, compound a

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: boy, half French, half English, that shall go to

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Constantinople and take the Turk by the beard?

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: shall we not? what sayest thou, my fair

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: flower-de-luce?

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: I do not know dat

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: No; 'tis hereafter to know, but now to promise: do

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: but now promise, Kate, you will endeavour for your

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: French part of such a boy; and for my English moiety

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: take the word of a king and a bachelor. How answer

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: you, la plus belle Katharine du monde, mon tres cher

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: et devin deesse?

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: Your majestee ave fausse French enough to deceive de

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: most sage demoiselle dat is en France.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Now, fie upon my false French! By mine honour, in

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: true English, I love thee, Kate: by which honour I

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: dare not swear thou lovest me; yet my blood begins to

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: flatter me that thou dost, notwithstanding the poor

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: and untempering effect of my visage. Now, beshrew

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: my father's ambition! he was thinking of civil wars

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: when he got me: therefore was I created with a

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: stubborn outside, with an aspect of iron, that, when

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: I come to woo ladies, I fright them. But, in faith,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Kate, the elder I wax, the better I shall appear:

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: my comfort is, that old age, that ill layer up of

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: beauty, can do no more, spoil upon my face: thou

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: hast me, if thou hast me, at the worst; and thou

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: shalt wear me, if thou wear me, better and better:

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: and therefore tell me, most fair Katharine, will you

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: have me? Put off your maiden blushes; avouch the

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: thoughts of your heart with the looks of an empress;

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: take me by the hand, and say 'Harry of England I am

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: thine:' which word thou shalt no sooner bless mine

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: ear withal, but I will tell thee aloud 'England is

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: thine, Ireland is thine, France is thine, and Harry

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Plantagenet is thine;' who though I speak it before

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: his face, if he be not fellow with the best king,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: thou shalt find the best king of good fellows.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Come, your answer in broken music; for thy voice is

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: music and thy English broken; therefore, queen of

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: all, Katharine, break thy mind to me in broken

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: English; wilt thou have me?

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: Dat is as it sall please de roi mon pere.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Nay, it will please him well, Kate it shall please

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: him, Kate.

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: Den it sall also content me.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Upon that I kiss your hand, and I call you my queen.

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: Laissez, mon seigneur, laissez, laissez: ma foi, je

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: ne veux point que vous abaissiez votre grandeur en

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: baisant la main d'une de votre seigeurie indigne

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: serviteur; excusez-moi, je vous supplie, mon

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: tres-puissant seigneur.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Then I will kiss your lips, Kate.

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: Les dames et demoiselles pour etre baisees devant

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: leur noces, il n'est pas la coutume de France.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Madam my interpreter, what says she?

speaker: ALICE
text_entry: Dat it is not be de fashion pour les ladies of

speaker: ALICE
text_entry: France,--I cannot tell vat is baiser en Anglish.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: To kiss.

speaker: ALICE
text_entry: Your majesty entendre bettre que moi.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: It is not a fashion for the maids in France to kiss

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: before they are married, would she say?

speaker: ALICE
text_entry: Oui, vraiment.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: O Kate, nice customs curtsy to great kings. Dear

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Kate, you and I cannot be confined within the weak

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: list of a country's fashion: we are the makers of

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: manners, Kate; and the liberty that follows our

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: places stops the mouth of all find-faults; as I will

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: do yours, for upholding the nice fashion of your

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: country in denying me a kiss: therefore, patiently

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: and yielding.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Kissing her

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: You have witchcraft in your lips, Kate: there is

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: more eloquence in a sugar touch of them than in the

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: tongues of the French council; and they should

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: sooner persuade Harry of England than a general

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: petition of monarchs. Here comes your father.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Re-enter the FRENCH KING and his QUEEN, BURGUNDY, and other Lords

speaker: BURGUNDY
text_entry: God save your majesty! my royal cousin, teach you

speaker: BURGUNDY
text_entry: our princess English?

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: I would have her learn, my fair cousin, how

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: perfectly I love her; and that is good English.

speaker: BURGUNDY
text_entry: Is she not apt?

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Our tongue is rough, coz, and my condition is not

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: smooth; so that, having neither the voice nor the

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: heart of flattery about me, I cannot so conjure up

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: the spirit of love in her, that he will appear in

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: his true likeness.

speaker: BURGUNDY
text_entry: Pardon the frankness of my mirth, if I answer you

speaker: BURGUNDY
text_entry: for that. If you would conjure in her, you must

speaker: BURGUNDY
text_entry: make a circle; if conjure up love in her in his true

speaker: BURGUNDY
text_entry: likeness, he must appear naked and blind. Can you

speaker: BURGUNDY
text_entry: blame her then, being a maid yet rosed over with the

speaker: BURGUNDY
text_entry: virgin crimson of modesty, if she deny the

speaker: BURGUNDY
text_entry: appearance of a naked blind boy in her naked seeing

speaker: BURGUNDY
text_entry: self? It were, my lord, a hard condition for a maid

speaker: BURGUNDY
text_entry: to consign to.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Yet they do wink and yield, as love is blind and enforces.

speaker: BURGUNDY
text_entry: They are then excused, my lord, when they see not

speaker: BURGUNDY
text_entry: what they do.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Then, good my lord, teach your cousin to consent winking.

speaker: BURGUNDY
text_entry: I will wink on her to consent, my lord, if you will

speaker: BURGUNDY
text_entry: teach her to know my meaning: for maids, well

speaker: BURGUNDY
text_entry: summered and warm kept, are like flies at

speaker: BURGUNDY
text_entry: Bartholomew-tide, blind, though they have their

speaker: BURGUNDY
text_entry: eyes; and then they will endure handling, which

speaker: BURGUNDY
text_entry: before would not abide looking on.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: This moral ties me over to time and a hot summer;

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: and so I shall catch the fly, your cousin, in the

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: latter end and she must be blind too.

speaker: BURGUNDY
text_entry: As love is, my lord, before it loves.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: It is so: and you may, some of you, thank love for

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: my blindness, who cannot see many a fair French city

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: for one fair French maid that stands in my way.

speaker: FRENCH KING
text_entry: Yes, my lord, you see them perspectively, the cities

speaker: FRENCH KING
text_entry: turned into a maid; for they are all girdled with

speaker: FRENCH KING
text_entry: maiden walls that war hath never entered.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Shall Kate be my wife?

speaker: FRENCH KING
text_entry: So please you.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: I am content; so the maiden cities you talk of may

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: wait on her: so the maid that stood in the way for

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: my wish shall show me the way to my will.

speaker: FRENCH KING
text_entry: We have consented to all terms of reason.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Is't so, my lords of England?

speaker: WESTMORELAND
text_entry: The king hath granted every article:

speaker: WESTMORELAND
text_entry: His daughter first, and then in sequel all,

speaker: WESTMORELAND
text_entry: According to their firm proposed natures.

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: Only he hath not yet subscribed this:

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: Where your majesty demands, that the King of France,

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: having any occasion to write for matter of grant,

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: shall name your highness in this form and with this

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: addition in French, Notre trescher fils Henri, Roi

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: d'Angleterre, Heritier de France; and thus in

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: Latin, Praeclarissimus filius noster Henricus, Rex

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: Angliae, et Haeres Franciae.

speaker: FRENCH KING
text_entry: Nor this I have not, brother, so denied,

speaker: FRENCH KING
text_entry: But your request shall make me let it pass.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: I pray you then, in love and dear alliance,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Let that one article rank with the rest;

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: And thereupon give me your daughter.

speaker: FRENCH KING
text_entry: Take her, fair son, and from her blood raise up

speaker: FRENCH KING
text_entry: Issue to me; that the contending kingdoms

speaker: FRENCH KING
text_entry: Of France and England, whose very shores look pale

speaker: FRENCH KING
text_entry: With envy of each other's happiness,

speaker: FRENCH KING
text_entry: May cease their hatred, and this dear conjunction

speaker: FRENCH KING
text_entry: Plant neighbourhood and Christian-like accord

speaker: FRENCH KING
text_entry: In their sweet bosoms, that never war advance

speaker: FRENCH KING
text_entry: His bleeding sword 'twixt England and fair France.

speaker: ALL
text_entry: Amen!

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Now, welcome, Kate: and bear me witness all,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: That here I kiss her as my sovereign queen.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Flourish

speaker: QUEEN ISABEL
text_entry: God, the best maker of all marriages,

speaker: QUEEN ISABEL
text_entry: Combine your hearts in one, your realms in one!

speaker: QUEEN ISABEL
text_entry: As man and wife, being two, are one in love,

speaker: QUEEN ISABEL
text_entry: So be there 'twixt your kingdoms such a spousal,

speaker: QUEEN ISABEL
text_entry: That never may ill office, or fell jealousy,

speaker: QUEEN ISABEL
text_entry: Which troubles oft the bed of blessed marriage,

speaker: QUEEN ISABEL
text_entry: Thrust in between the paction of these kingdoms,

speaker: QUEEN ISABEL
text_entry: To make divorce of their incorporate league;

speaker: QUEEN ISABEL
text_entry: That English may as French, French Englishmen,

speaker: QUEEN ISABEL
text_entry: Receive each other. God speak this Amen!

speaker: ALL
text_entry: Amen!

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Prepare we for our marriage--on which day,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: My Lord of Burgundy, we'll take your oath,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: And all the peers', for surety of our leagues.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Then shall I swear to Kate, and you to me;

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: And may our oaths well kept and prosperous be!

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Sennet. Exeunt

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: EPILOGUE

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Enter Chorus

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: Thus far, with rough and all-unable pen,

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: Our bending author hath pursued the story,

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: In little room confining mighty men,

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: Mangling by starts the full course of their glory.

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: Small time, but in that small most greatly lived

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: This star of England: Fortune made his sword;

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: By which the world's best garden be achieved,

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: And of it left his son imperial lord.

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: Henry the Sixth, in infant bands crown'd King

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: Of France and England, did this king succeed;

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: Whose state so many had the managing,

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: That they lost France and made his England bleed:

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: Which oft our stage hath shown; and, for their sake,

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: In your fair minds let this acceptance take.

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: Exit
